description: A man suspected of holding at least one hostage in a Pittsburgh office tower has been apparently updating his Facebook account as the drama unfolds.
caption: thelede.blogs.nytimes.com

name: Gangnam Style, Original and in Imitation
message: 'Gangnam Style' is so viral it's even crossed the DMZ into North Korea: http://nyti.ms/R5BfOB. Watch the original video by South Korean rapper PSY and see 8 imitation videos below. Which video is your favorite?
description: “Gangnam Style,” a music video by a South Korean rapper known as PSY, has been viewed over 220 million times on YouTube. It’s also been redone by motivated fans in video imitations as over the top as the original.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Romney to Release 2011 Tax Returns
message: Mitt Romney's campaign announced his intention to release his 2011 tax returns today. Additionally, he'll provide a summary of his tax liability from 1990 to 2009.Do you think Mr. Romney's action will end the debate about his taxes?
description: Mitt Romney paid $1.95 million in taxes on his 2011 investment income of $13.7 million, his campaign revealed on Friday, saying it will make good at 3 p.m. this afternoon on Mr. Romney's promise earlier this year to eventually release his full returns for that year.
caption: thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com

name: NULL
message: We are currently working with Facebook to resolve an issue which prevents the article headline, summary and thumbnail image from being published on Facebook when readers share some New York Times links. We hope to resolve the issue within the next 24 hours. We apologize for the inconvenience and thank you for your patience.
description: NULL
caption: NULL

name: Coptic Scholars Doubt and Hail a Reference to Jesus’ Wife
message: When Karen L. King, a historian of early Christianity, announced this week that she had identified a fragment of ancient Coptic text in which Jesus utters the words “my wife,” she said she was making the finding public — despite many unresolved questions — so that her academic colleagues could weigh in. And weigh in, they have.
description: A historian’s finding of a fragment of ancient Coptic text in which Jesus is said to utter the words “my wife” has drawn strong reaction from Christian scholars.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Troop Surge in Afghanistan Ends With Little Fanfare
message: The American troop surge in Afghanistan is now over, but the post-mortems have just begun.
description: The milestone, which still leaves 68,000 American troops in Afghanistan, went nearly unremarked in the country, with no statement from President Hamid Karzai or the United States military commander, Gen. John R. Allen.
caption: nytimes.com

name: When the White House Speaks on the Campaign Trail - Room for Debate
message: How have presidents used executive power to get re-elected? Is this an abuse of power, or just the usual “incumbency advantage”? Let Room for Debate know what you think.
description: How have presidents used executive power to get re-elected? Is this an abuse of power, or just the usual “incumbency advantage”?
caption: nytimes.com

name: Quiz: Are You Addicted to Food?
message: Are you a food addict? Several studies now suggest that food and drug addictions have much in common, particularly in the way that both disrupt the parts of the brain involved in pleasure and self-control. Like Well | The New York Times and take the quiz at the link below.
description: Find out if you are prone to food addiction. Take the Well quiz.
caption: well.blogs.nytimes.com

name: Man Critically Injured by Tiger at Bronx Zoo
message: A man in his 20s or 30s was critically injured Friday afternoon after he fell or jumped from a monorail at the Bronx Zoo and landed in the tiger habitat, where he was attacked by a tiger, the Fire Department said.
description: The man, who fell or jumped from the monorail into the tiger habitat, may have 'severe deep cuts to his back' and a severe leg injury, an official said.
caption: cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com

name: At the Track, Racing Economics Collide With Veterinarians’ Oath
message: Quotation of the Day: 'If a horse is sound, why does it need all these drugs? I never gave consent.' - Susan Kayne, owner of Bourbon Bandit, on veterinary treatment of the horse.
description: Horse-racing veterinarians are both doctor and drugstore; the more drugs they prescribe, the more money they make.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Chief Censor in Myanmar Caps His Red Pen
message: “We didn’t arrest or torture anyone, but we had to torture their writing,” U Tint Swe said, his serious expression yielding to a faint smile. A month ago Mr. Tint Swe summoned the country’s leading editors and publishers and made a grand announcement: after 48 years and 14 days, censorship was bound for the junkyard of history.
description: U Tint Swe, head of Myanmar’s Press Scrutiny and Registration Division, is closing down the office after 48 years amid democratic reforms.
caption: nytimes.com

name: TimesTalks Madrid Live Webcast
message: NULL
description: TimesTalks is coming to you live from Madrid September 21 - 23. Watch live webcasts (http://bit.ly/NIGvrT) for free with the following luminaries of film, theater and music:Jeremy IronsAlison KlaymanTom HiddlestonBenh ZeitlinJuan Antonio BayonaJulie TaymorTori AmosTune in at http://bit.ly/NIGvrT all weekend!
caption: TimesTalks Madrid Live Webcast

name: The New York Times
message: If you’ve ever wanted to see what New York City’s pre-eminent statue of Christopher Columbus looks like standing on a large coffee table in an upscale New York living room with killer views, now is your chance: http://nyti.ms/ROISpE
description: Roberta Smith writes: “Under the auspices of the Public Art Fund, the Japanese artist Tatzu Nishi has built a convincingly appointed penthouse-worthy space around the 13-foot-high marble sculpture of Columbus that has presided over Columbus Circle from a height of 60 feet since it was completed by Gaetano Russo in 1892. In doing so, Mr. Nishi has achieved a nifty bit of Surrealist displacement without moving the sculpture an inch.” Read more and see additional photos: http://nyti.ms/ROISpE (Photo by Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)
caption: NULL

name: Egyptian Leader Mohamed Morsi Spells Out Terms for U.S.-Arab Ties
message: In Cairo, Steven Erlanger and David Kirkpatrick of The Times spoke to Egypt's new president, Mohamed Morsi, in an exclusive interview about a range of topics, including his country's relationship with the U.S. and his association with the Muslim Brotherhood. The article includes audio excerpts from their interview and the reporters are taking your questions about Mr. Morsi and Egypt.If you would like the reporters to respond to your comments and questions, please post them inside the article.
description: On the eve of his first trip to the United States as Egypt’s president, Mohamed Morsi said the United States must fundamentally change its approach to the Arab world.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Hard Lines, Red Lines and Green Lines
message: 'Aung San Suu Kyi gave up 20 years of her life for her country. Many leaders today won’t even give up a news cycle,' writes Op-Ed columnist Thomas L. Friedman.
description: Aung San Suu Kyi hit the nail on the head last week when she said it is the fear of losing power that corrupts. It’s everywhere these days.
caption: nytimes.com

name: T: The New York Times Style Magazine
message: Claire Danes is featured in T Magazine's Fall Travel issue. Read the profile of the 'Homeland' actress and learn how Ms. Danes approaches the role of Carrie Mathison:http://nyti.ms/NKEWJT.
description: Check out our Fall Travel issue cover, featuring Claire Danes. Read our profile of the 'Homeland' actress: http://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/21/t-magazine/claire-danes-goes-rogue.html?ref=travel-issue
caption: NULL

name: Where Is Cuba Going?
message: Not long ago, there were smart people who doubted that such a thing as a post-Fidel Cuba could even exist. What comes after the Castros is as much of a mystery as ever.
description: Not long ago, there were smart people who doubted that such a thing as a post-Fidel Cuba could even exist. What comes after the Castros is as much of a mystery as ever.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Middle Schools Add a Team Rule: Get a Drug Test
message: Children in grades as low as middle school are being told that providing a urine sample is required to play sports or participate in extracurricular activities like drama and choir. Do you think drug testing at the middle school level is appropriate?
description: Required screening for participation in athletics or other activities can begin as early as middle school, confusing students and stirring objections from parents.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Into the Cloud
message: In processing a staggering amount of Internet activity, data centers waste vast amounts of energy, belying the information industry’s image of eco-friendliness. Learn more about cloud factories in 'Power, Pollution and the Internet': http://nyti.ms/Q9Q1nX.
description: James Glanz of The New York Times and Ken Brill, founder of the Uptime Institute, tour a data center and show what is required to keep it going around the clock.
caption: nytimes.com

name: In Kennedy Recordings, History’s Raw Materials
message: Listen to a selection of excerpts from the secret recordings made by President John F. Kennedy at the link below.
description: Secret recordings made by President Kennedy, which include Oval Office discussions about Cuba and space exploration, will now be made accessible to the general public.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The Emmy Awards 2012 Live Blog
message: The glitz! The glamour! Color, and a lot of cleavage! New York Times reporters are on the red carpet gearing up for the Emmy Awards. Join them at our live blog all the way through the ceremony tonight. Do you have a favorite Emmys red carpet moment? Share it at the live blog: http://nyti.ms/Uqso8Y
description: The 64th Primetime Emmy Awards are tonight and Dave Itzkoff, Mike Hale, Brian Stelter and others will be providing analysis of the TV shows honored - and left out - during the broadcast. Stuart Emmrich will have insights from the red carpet before the show.
caption: artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com

name: Live Coverage of the Emmys
message: And the Emmy goes to... The show has begun. Follow along with us! See a slide show of the nominees here: http://nyti.ms/NLlVXU
description: The fashion, the competition, the pomp and circumstance. Watch the Emmy Awards tonight with news and analysis from New York Times reporters and editors.
caption: artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com

name: Emmy Awards 2012 Red Carpet
message: Were your favorite shows or performers recognized with Emmy Awards tonight? See the full list of Emmy winners and review our coverage of the ceremony on: http://nyti.ms/QbEhBC. Browse photos from the red carpet below.
description: Looks from the crimson runway at 64th annual Emmy Awards.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Study Divides Breast Cancer Into Four Distinct Types
message: Quotation of the Day: 'This is the road map for how we might cure breast cancer in the future.' - Dr. Matthew Ellis, of Washington University, a researcher for a new study that has identified four genetically distinct types of the cancer.
description: New findings are reshaping the understanding of breast cancer, pointing to the use of drugs approved for other cancers. “This is the road map for how we might cure breast cancer in the future,” a researcher said.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Eating for Health, Not Weight
message: Op-Ed contributor Dean Ornish writes, 'Never underestimate the power of telling people what they want to hear — like cheeseburgers and bacon are good for you.'
description: The best diet is low in unhealthful carbs and low in fat as well as in red meat and processed foods.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The New World
message: By the beginning of the 21st century, the world map seemed pretty much complete. Now, though, we appear on the brink of yet another nation-state baby boom,' write Op-Ed contributors Frank Jacobs and Parag Khanna. Explore an interactive map at the link below to see how our international borders might shift.
description: An interactive series of maps show possible new additions to the world’s list of independent nations.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The New York Times
message: Greenland’s receding ice has exposed vast deposits of valuable minerals and new opportunities for an island in economic decline:  http://nyti.ms/QtQSQp
description: Greenland’s receding ice has exposed vast deposits of valuable minerals and new opportunities for an island in economic decline. Watch our 4-minute video report 'Greenland's Unfrozen Future': http://nyti.ms/QtQSQp (Photo by Andrew Testa for The New York Times)
caption: NULL

name: For Vice President, a Heartbeat Away From the Public Isn’t Close Enough
message: Politicians have always pressed the flesh. But few relish doing so as heartily as Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. His old-fashioned style turns out to be well suited to an age in which a photograph of a spontaneous encounter with a voter can spread through social media and deliver the impression that politicians are just like us.
description: Politicians have always pressed the flesh, but few relish doing so as heartily as Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Foxconn Plant in China Closed After Worker Riot
message: Foxconn Technology, a major supplier to some of the world’s electronics giants, including Apple, said it had closed one of its large Chinese plants Monday after the police were called in to break up a fight among factory employees. Follow updates by visiting the link below.
description: A spokesman said a fight among employees on Sunday night turned into a riot that had to be broken up by thousands of police officers.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Rethinking Sleep
message: Do you aim to get eight hours of sleep each night? Op-Ed contributor David K. Randall suggests the emphasis on a straight eight-hour sleep has outlived its usefulness.
description: It’s not the quantity of sleep that restores and refreshes, but the quality.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Conservatives Want to ‘Let Ryan Be Ryan’ on Campaign Trail
message: “If someone says you’re going to change Medicare as we know it, you say, ‘You’re damned right.’ Paul Ryan can give that answer,” Chris Chocola, president of the conservative political action committee Club for Growth, said. “The Romney ticket would be well served to let Paul Ryan be Paul Ryan.”
description: Representative Paul D. Ryan’s slow fade into the afterthought role usually played by running mates has given Republicans a new outlet for frustration over the state of the race.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Timeline Photos
message: Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof is about to start an AMA on Reddit: http://nyti.ms/QefzAl. Put him on the spot! You can also subscribe to Mr. Kristof's updates here on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/kristof
description: NULL
caption: NULL

name: Deciding When a Pet Has Suffered Enough
message: Have you ever cared for a pet that was in pain? How did you deal with the experience? Op-Ed contributor Jessica Pierce writes, 'For the vast majority of companion animals, death will be orchestrated by a human caretaker, the time and date chosen in advance and not, as it were, decided by 'nature' or some higher power. Yet despite its ubiquity, we rarely question its moral appropriateness.'
description: Euthanasia is often the de facto solution for animal pain, even when palliative care is a better option.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Data Barns in a Farm Town, Gobbling Power and Flexing Muscle
message: This is the second article in our series about the physical structures that make up the cloud, and their impact on our environment. Read the first article in 'The Cloud Factories' series here: http://nyti.ms/Q9Q1nX.
description: When Internet factories come to town, they can feel less like their sleek, clean and convenient image and more like old-time manufacturing.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Tim Burton, at Home in His Own Head
message: “Wanting people to like you is nice, but I’m confident that there’s always going to be lots that don’t,” Tim Burton said with gallows humor and genuine pride. “I’ll always be able to hang on to that.” How about you? Do you like Tim Burton's work? If so, what's your favorite Tim Burton creation?
description: The director of “Beetlejuice,” “Batman” and the new “Frankenweenie” may be cinema’s most widely embraced loner.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Apple’s Feud With Google Is Now Felt on iPhone
message: “It’s the two big kids kicking sand in the sandbox,” said Colin Gillis, an analyst who covers Google and Apple for BGC Partners.
description: Once the best of friends, Google and Apple are battling in courtrooms and in the consumer marketplace, with iPhone users in the cross-fire after Apple removed Google’s maps app and YouTube.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Spain Recoils as Its Hungry Forage Trash Bins for a Next Meal
message: Quotation of the Day: 'This is my pension.' - Victor Victorio, 67, who forages for fruits and vegetables in the garbage at a market in Madrid.
description: As the economy worsens, some residents of Spain are turning to garbage bins in search of discarded food.
caption: nytimes.com

name: We Are the 96 Percent
message: 'Nearly all Americans have used government social policies at some point in their lives. The beneficiaries include the rich and the poor, Democrats and Republicans. Almost everyone is both a maker and a taker,' write Suzanne Mettler and John Sides in the Opinion Pages.
description: Democrat or Republican, we are all both makers and takers.
caption: campaignstops.blogs.nytimes.com

name: In Arab Spring, Obama Finds a Sharp Test
message: President Obama has learned that bold words and support for democratic aspirations are not enough to engender good will in the Arab world.
description: In the almost two years of political turmoil in the Arab world, President Obama has learned that bold words and support for democratic aspirations are not enough to engender good will in the region.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Replacement Refs Turn Hail Mary Pass Into an OMG Moment
message: 'It was, in a word, absurd. But in this N.F.L. season it was not atypical. It was Monday.' Did you see the Green Bay Packers/Seattle Seahawks game? How would you like the N.F.L. to respond?
description: The late calls by replacement officials in Monday night’s N.F.L. game, on the final play especially, marred an otherwise magical finish and struck at the very integrity of the sport.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The New York Times
message: What do you think of President Obama's speech to the United Nations? Read the full text of the speech: http://nyti.ms/PVGGOP
description: At the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday, President Obama warned against a nuclear-armed Iran and spoke about the recent anti-American protests in the Arab world, urging the gathered body to 'speak honestly about the deeper causes of this crisis.' Read the full text of President Obama's speech: http://nyti.ms/PVGGOP. (Photo by Damon Winter/The New York Times)
caption: NULL

name: How the Center of the Earth Got a Little Off Kilter
message: How did the Middle of the World wind up being not quite at the middle of the world?
description: At Ecuador’s Middle of the World park, tourists stand on a yellow line that is said to be precisely at Earth’s midpoint. Except that it is not. The Equator is hundreds of feet north.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Tagging Great Whites
message: On Sept. 13 a giant shark that would become known as Genie became the first great white — all 2,292 pounds of her — to be captured live off Cape Cod, the home waters of “Jaws.” Watch a 2-minute video (http://nyti.ms/Qw3hTQ) on the catch.
description: A team of scientists is tagging great white sharks off Cape Cod in an effort to understand their migratory patterns and breeding habits and better protect them.
caption: nytimes.com

name: America the Anxious
message: Take a look at your own updates on Facebook. Are your posts more positive or cynical? 'Blindfold me and read out the Facebook statuses of my friends, without their names, and I will tell you which are American and which are British,' writes Ruth Whippman in the Opinion Pages. 'Americans post links to inspirational stories, and parenting blogs packed with life lessons. (British parenting blogs tend to be packed with despair and feces.) My American friends post heartwarming messages of support to one another, and often themselves, while my British cohort’s updates are usually some variation on 'This is rubbish.' '
description: The British may be dour, but across the pond, the obsessive American pursuit of happiness is creating a nation of nervous wrecks.
caption: opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com

name: The Conservative Mind
message: 'Conservatism has lost the balance between economic and traditional conservatism. The Republican Party has abandoned half of its intellectual ammunition. It appeals to people as potential business owners, but not as parents, neighbors and citizens,' writes Op-Ed columnist David Brooks.
description: Conservatism has lost half of its intellectual firepower. Republicans need to recover traditional conservatism or risk becoming irrelevant.
caption: nytimes.com

name: When Surgeons Leave Objects Behind
message: Every year, an estimated 4,000 cases of “retained surgical items,” as they are known in the medical world, are reported in the United States. These are items left in the patient’s body after surgery. Well | The New York Times reports on what can be done to remedy the problem.
description: Every year in the United States, 4,000 cases of 'retained surgical items' -- clamps, scalpels, scissors and sponges -- are left inside a patient's body after surgery.
caption: well.blogs.nytimes.com

name: The New York Times Food
message: Now is the time of the crab. http://nyti.ms/NPsyIK
description: Atlantic blue crabs, or “tasty beautiful swimmers,” are currently in their fat and plentiful prime. Pair them with corn and tomatoes for a September feast: http://nyti.ms/NPsyIK (Photo: Sabra Krock for The New York Times)
caption: NULL

name: He’s Playing Our Song
message: 'A friend whom we had sat with at the prom posted a photo of that fateful evening on Facebook, tagging me. When I clicked on the notification, there we were. Then I saw that his sister had commented: 'My brother would kill you for posting this.' ' writes Mariclare Lawson in this week's Modern Love column.
description: He told me there was someone loving me all those years. Him.
caption: nytimes.com

name: For Oreo Campaign Finale, a Twist on Collaboration
message: Have you seen Oreo's Daily Twist campaign? The Times's advertising columnist Stuart Elliott takes a look at the campaign which includes ads highlighting the Mars rover, gay pride, Elvis Presley Week and Talk Like a Pirate Day.
description: Kraft Foods, the maker of Oreo cookies, and a team of agencies will be working live with consumers to produce the final ad of the brand’s Daily Twist campaign.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Training Afghan Allies, With Guard Firmly Up
message: Quotation of the Day: 'We would have killed many of them already, but our commanders are cowards and don’t let us.' - Abdul Hanan, an Afghan soldier, on American military advisers.
description: After recent attacks by Afghan forces against Western soldiers and Marines, American military advisers are extremely wary, laying bare the challenge of preparing the Afghans to fight on their own.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Tolerance, Up in Flames
message: Op-Ed contributor Steve Inskeep writes, 'What the protesters really oppose, though they may not realize it, is the nature of their own country. Pakistan is a cultural crossroads with many languages and religious sects, and the Nishat’s eclectic screenings mirrored the nation. Cultural diversity, like alcohol, quietly persists, but it is being driven underground by intolerant brands of Islam.'
description: A cinema attack was not about American influence or anti-Muslim videos. Pakistani extremists are attacking, and destroying, their country’s own values and traditions.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Violence Erupts as Greeks Strike to Protest Austerity
message: Widespread protests erupted across Greece on Wednesday as trade unions called a nationwide strike to contest billions of euros in new salary and pension cuts being discussed by the government and its international creditors.
description: Widespread protests erupted across Greece on Wednesday after trade unions called a nationwide strike to contest new salary and pension cuts being discussed by the government.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The Roses Are a Draw. (So Is the Dress Code.)
message: Get naked. Stop and smell the roses.
description: Abbey House Gardens is known for its 2,000 varieties of roses, its mix of landscaped and wild paths, and the six days during the summer when clothing is optional.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Andy Williams, Crooner of ‘Moon River,’ Dies at 84
message: Look back at the life and work of Andy Williams. During his 2007 tour in Britain he attributed his longevity to the joy of performing: “Perhaps that two hours out onstage is the medicine that everybody should have.”
description: Mr. Williams became famous for his smooth easy-listening style and his successful TV shows of the 1960s.
caption: nytimes.com

name: N.F.L. and Referees Are Close to a Deal
message: The N.F.L. and the referees’ union are close to reaching an agreement to end the lockout, but a remaining issue is how quickly the regular N.F.L. referees can return to work.
description: The N.F.L. and the referees’ union are close to reaching an agreement to end the lockout, but a remaining issue is how quickly the regular N.F.L. referees can return to work.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The New York Times
message: In deciding whom you would like to see elected president this year, which issues will be most important to you?
description: The latest Quinnipiac University/The New York Times/CBS News poll (http://nyti.ms/VJ6DUk) shows that President Obama has widened his lead over Mitt Romney and is outperforming him on nearly every major campaign issue. The poll also found potential openings where Mr. Romney could gain support. More voters say Mr. Romney would be better than Mr. Obama at tackling the budget deficit — the only major issue where he had such an edge — and a majority agree with his assertions that the government is doing too much of what should be left to individuals and businesses. Read more about the full poll results here: http://nyti.ms/VJ6DUk
caption: NULL

name: Taxes Threaten an Island Culture in Georgia
message: Sapelo Island, a tangle of salt marsh and sand reachable only by boat, holds the largest community of people who identify themselves as saltwater Geechees. Sometimes called the Gullahs, these Creole-speaking descendants of slaves have inhabited the nation’s southeast coast for more than two centuries. Theirs is one of the most fragile cultures in America.
description: Increasing economic pressures are forcing the saltwater Geechees of Sapelo Island, Ga., to wonder if their fragile community will finally succumb to cultural erosion.
caption: nytimes.com

name: U.N. Speech by Iranian President Lacks Fire of Years Past
message: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran gave a subdued speech at the United Nations on Wednesday, sticking largely to spiritual and moral themes, rather than his usual annual broadside lambasting Israel, the lack of peace in the Middle East conflict and international efforts to dismantle Iran’s nuclear program.
description: Mahmoud Ahmadinejad stuck to largely spiritual and moral themes, rather than giving his annual broadside, lambasting Israel and international efforts to dismantle Iran’s nuclear program.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Stuyvesant Students Describe the How and the Why of Cheating
message: Did you ever cheat in school? If you have cheated, how did you rationalize the decision? A senior at Stuyvesant High School said: “It’s like, ‘I’ll keep my integrity and fail this test’ — no. No one wants to fail a test. You could study for two hours and get an 80, or you could take a risk and get a 90.”
description: Former and current students at Stuyvesant High School say lower-level cheating is part of the culture, and students employ several rationales for choosing to be dishonest.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Proportion Control
message: Its devotees will tell you it’s ubiquitous in nature, art and architecture. And there are plastic surgeons and financial mavens who will tell you it’s the secret to pretty faces and handsome returns. Approximately equal to 1.618 and denoted by the Greek letter phi, the golden ratio has been canonized as the “Divine Proportion.”
description: Separating the myth from the math in the golden ratio, the second-most famous irrational number.
caption: opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com

name: Why Not Debtors’ Prison?
message: 'The Romney campaign has turned conservative theory into ideology and gone off the cliff with it. If you want to inspire, lead and unite people, it won’t fly to take ideologically driven findings and present them unvarnished to voters,' writes Op-Ed columnist Maureen Dowd.
description: In a dog-eat-dog world, President Obama is the cat, and Mitt Romney is chasing his own tail.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The New York Times
message: AUTUMNA poem by Yevgeny Yevtushenko: http://nyti.ms/RZ3rpe
description: AUTUMNA poem by Yevgeny Yevtushenko: http://nyti.ms/RZ3rpe(Photo by Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)
caption: NULL

name: Making Vegan a New Normal
message: Is plant-based eating the way of the future? A new fountain of youth? That’s anybody’s guess. But in Los Angeles, plenty of people are willing to give pumpkinseed chorizo and parsnip bacon a try.
description: From power tables in Beverly Hills to pubs in the San Fernando Valley, the surge in popularity of plant-based diets is drastically changing the dining landscape.
caption: nytimes.com

name: NULL
message: N.F.L. and Referees Union Agree on Deal to End Lockout. Stay tuned to http://nyti.ms/SS7ZIv for more details.
description: NULL
caption: NULL

name: N.F.L. Reaches Labor Deal With Referees
message: The National Football League reached agreement on an eight-year labor deal with its game officials late Wednesday night, ending the lockout that forced unprepared replacement referees onto the field. Judy Battista reports with more details in the article below.
description: With a new eight-year deal in place, regular officials will work Thursday’s Ravens-Browns game, and the officials’ union will vote Friday to ratify the contract and work Sunday’s games.
caption: nytimes.com

name: China Politics Stall Overhaul for Economy
message: Quotation of the Day: 'The slogans are loud and the plans are grand, but when it comes to implementation, the constraints are many.' - Zhao Xijun, a professor in Beijing, on a lack of economic progress during a transition in China’s leadership.
description: China’s Communist Party appears so distracted by its leadership transition that it is not pursuing the bold agenda that may be necessary to prevent severe economic pain.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Backlash to the Backlash
message: Op-Ed columnist Thomas L. Friedman writes, 'There is no question that we need a respectful dialogue between Islam and the West, but, even more, we need a respectful dialogue between Muslims and Muslims.'
description: Muslim moderates have been fighting back. While it’s not clear whether the trend can be sustained, it’s certainly worth watching.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Book Review: ‘The Casual Vacancy’ by J. K. Rowling
message: Is J.K. Rowling's new novel 'The Casual Vacancy' on your reading list?  'This novel for adults is filled with a variety of people like Harry’s aunt and uncle, Petunia and Vernon Dursley: self-absorbed, small-minded, snobbish and judgmental folks, whose stories neither engage nor transport us,' writes Michiko Kakutani in her review of Ms. Rowling's new book.
description: The bitter citizens of a small English town are the focus in “The Casual Vacancy,” J. K. Rowling’s new novel for adults.
caption: nytimes.com

name: In Texas Conviction, an Immigrant Rallying Cry
message: “I believe now, as I did at the time of the trial, that there is a substantial likelihood that the defendant was not guilty of this offense,” Jon Wisser, the trial judge, said in a letter to the district attorney last month. In January, Rosa Jimenez, an illegal Mexican immigrant, will have spent 10 years in a Texas prison for a crime she says she did not commit.
description: Rosa Jimenez, an illegal Mexican immigrant in a Texas prison for a crime she says she did not commit, has become a cause célèbre for critics of the American criminal justice system.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Election May Decide When Interrogation Amounts to Torture
message: Neither Barack Obama nor Mitt Romney has said much about torture as part of terror investigations during the 2012 general campaign. But the future of American government practices when interrogating high-level terrorism suspects appears likely to turn on the outcome of the presidential election.
description: Neither President Obama nor Mitt Romney has said much about torture as part of terror investigations during the 2012 general campaign.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Video: Fighting for Idlib
message: Embedded with Syrian rebels, C.J. Chivers reports: 'Roughly two months into this important yet scarcely documented battle, Syria’s antigovernment fighters have succeeded in laying siege to the heavily fortified Abu ad Duhur air base.' Read more (http://nyti.ms/QXbjCV) and watch the video report below.
description: Facing a foe with superior weapons and firepower, the Syrian rebels wage an impassioned and complex fight.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Dear Waldorf, Mummy Stole Your Teapot Back in 1935. So Sorry.
message: Have you ever 'secretly checked out' an item from a hotel? Bring back our spoons, the Waldorf said. Our forks. Our long-lost teapots that had been “secretly checked out,” as the hotel put it on its Facebook page. “We’re giving you the chance to give it back, no questions asked.”
description: When the Waldorf-Astoria advertised an amnesty program for the return of items like hotel knives, coffee pots or perhaps ashtrays that left in guests' luggage -- no questions asked -- it worked.
caption: cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com

name: Resort’s Snow Won’t Be Pure This Year; It’ll Be Sewage
message: This coming ski season, the resort, Arizona Snowbowl, will become the first ski resort in the world to use 100 percent sewage effluent to make artificial snow.
description: Arizona Snowbowl will become the first ski resort in the world to use 100 percent sewage effluent to make artificial snow. Members of the Navajo tribe say the snow will ruin sacred ground.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Timeline Photos
message: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel displayed a  diagram while speaking about Iran's nuclear program at the U.N. on Thursday (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times).Mr. Netanyahu warned in his address that Iran's ability to build a nuclear bomb was near. Read about his speech here: http://nyti.ms/STmyeODo you think his speech was effective?
description: NULL
caption: NULL

name: Why Am I Going Gray?
message: Have you found any gray hair on your head? At what age did you spot your first gray? For our younger readers, when did you first notice your parents going gray? Read more articles from 'Booming' here: http://nyti.ms/Paw1xp
description: The idea of hair “going gray” is a bit of a misnomer, as the only thing going anywhere is a pigment called melanin.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Boogaard’s Lawsuit May Shake Up Hockey
message: The lawsuit brought by the family of the professional hockey player Derek Boogaard against the N.H.L.’s players union could lead to some novel and tumultuous territory for the sport.Revisit our 'Punched Out' series on Derek Boogaard: http://nyti.ms/RlMP8w. Over six months, The New York Times examined the life and death of Boogaard, who rose to fame as one of the sport's most feared fighters before dying at age 28 in May 2011.
description: A lawsuit filed by Derek Boogaard’s family accuses the players union of squandering a chance at a financial claim. But it also contains serious charges that could be explored.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The New York Times
message: A prize-winning pumpkin at the 36th Common Ground Country Fair in Maine. See more photos: http://nyti.ms/PaMFx1
description: The 36th Common Ground Country Fair organized by the Maine Organic Farmers and Gardeners Association drew 59,000 people this year. The fair is a grand celebration not only for organic growers, but also for spinners and weavers; woodworkers and jewelry-makers; drovers of oxen, horses and mules; and sheep herders and their dogs. Not to mention poets and fiddlers, reflexologists and herbalists, solar and wind power gurus, seed savers and worm-keepers. See more photos and read more about this year's fair: http://nyti.ms/PaMFx1 (Photo by Stacey Cramp for The New York Times)
caption: NULL

name: September, November: 40 Precious Days to Spend on Early Vote
message: Quotation of the Day: 'It has made the October surprises way less relevant. In a close election, you can increase your number of voters in a very important way.' - Jim Messina, President Obama’s campaign manager, who has built the president’s re-election strategy around the growing trend of voting early.
description: A stream of voters arrived at election offices across Iowa to cast their ballots, and waves of absentee ballots have started landing in mailboxes in 30 other states.
caption: thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com

name: The Psych Approach
message: 'When you look over the domestic policy landscape, you see all these different people in different policy silos with different budgets: in health care, education, crime, poverty, social mobility and labor force issues. But, in their disjointed ways, they are all dealing with the same problem — that across vast stretches of America, economic, social and family breakdowns are producing enormous amounts of stress and unregulated behavior, which dulls motivation, undermines self-control and distorts lives,' writes Op-Ed columnist David Brooks.
description: There are strong links between our childhood experiences and adult lives. The emotional basis of success should have a bigger role in education.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Tim Cook Apologizes for Apple's Maps
message: Has Apple's Maps problem made you less likely to buy aniPhone?
description: Complaints and jokes about Apple's new maps have not stopped since the company released iOS 6 last week, a software update that replaced Google's maps with its own. Now the company's chief executive, Tim Cook, is apologizing.
caption: bits.blogs.nytimes.com

name: Veterans Wait for Benefits as Claims Pile Up
message: Doris Hink, 89, has dementia and is the widow of a World War II veteran. The Department of Veterans Affairs took nearly two years to process her claim for a survivor’s pension, forcing her daughter to take $12,000 from savings to pay nursing home bills.The crushing inventory of claims for disability, pension and educational benefits that has overwhelmed the Department of Veterans Affairs has become known as 'the backlog.' For hundreds of thousands of veterans, the result has been long waits for decisions, mishandled documents, confusing communications and infuriating mistakes in their claims.
description: A crushing inventory of claims for disability, pension and educational benefits has overwhelmed the Department of Veterans Affairs.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Obama Fills in Blanks of Romney’s Plans, and G.O.P. Sees Falsehoods
message: The Obama campaign has run advertisements taking advantage of the many unknown details of Mitt Romney’s policy proposals by filling in the blanks in the least flattering light, often relying on the findings of research organizations. In doing so, the Obama campaign has leveled some charges that are more specific than the known facts warrant and others that are most likely wrong.Do you think the Obama campaign is playing fair by furnishing details where the Romney campaign has not been more specific?
description: The Obama campaign is taking advantage of the unknown details of Mitt Romney’s policy proposals by filling in the blanks, but some charges are more specific than the facts warrant.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Vatican Says Papyrus Referring to Jesus’ Wife Is Probably Fake
message: Do you think the Vatican is right to suspect that the papyrus fragment referring to 'Jesus' wife' is a forgery?
description: The Vatican called the fragment of a Coptic text “problematic and controversial,” and most likely an “inept forgery.”
caption: nytimes.com

name: How Exercise Can Help You Master New Skills
message: The next time you think you've perfected the snap of your tennis serve or the spin on your soccer kick, go for a run immediately afterward, and your body may better remember how to execute the skill again.
description: Physical exercise may help the brain to consolidate and store muscle memories, a new study found.
caption: well.blogs.nytimes.com

name: Which Language and Grammar Rules to Flout - Room for Debate
message: So many well-intentioned editors have fought to change “a historic” to “an historic.” If it turns out that the guidelines we cling to (“to which we cling”?) are nonsense, maybe the texters have the right idea when they throw out the old rules and start fresh. Room for Debate asks: Where do good language and grammar rules come from, and how do bad ones catch on?
description: How can we tell the difference between a sound rule of English and a made-up shibboleth? How do the nonsense rules catch on?
caption: nytimes.com

name: New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center
message: “Life of Pi,” Ang Lee’s adaptation of Yann Martel’s best-selling novel, is the opening-night selection at the 50th New York Film Festival. A.O. Scott writes that it's an 'unusual opening-night choice both for its crowd-pleasing sincerity and for its sheer visual grandeur.' Have you read the novel? Do you plan on seeing the film adaptation?
description: The 50th New York Film Festival is as eclectic as ever, with Hollywood products like “Life of Pi,” foreign award winners like “Amour” and independent offerings like “Frances Ha.”
caption: nytimes.com

name: Chastened King Seeks Redemption, for Spain and His Monarchy
message: Quotation of the Day: 'The monarchy will continue as long as the people want a monarchy.' - King Juan Carlos, of Spain.
description: With the country in an economic slump and the monarchy itself under fire, King Juan Carlos is reasserting himself into Spain’s public life and embracing his role as an economic booster.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The New York Times
message: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the publisher of The New York Times from 1963 to 1992, has died at the age of 86. Among his legacies to The Times is the bold decision he made in publishing the Pentagon Papers, Washington's secret history of the Vietnam War. 'It was a defining moment for him and, in the view of many journalists and historians, his finest,' writes Clyde Haberman in Mr. Sulzberger's obituary: http://nyti.ms/Sr8aOK
description: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger answers questions, on June 16, 1971, at a news conference about the publication of the Pentagon Papers. (Photo: Barton Silverman/The New York Times) Read the complete obituary: http://nyti.ms/Sr8aOKWatch a video about Mr. Sulzberger's life and career: http://nyti.ms/SmdsHrMore images of Mr. Sulzberger in childhood, as a Marine and as publisher of The Times: http://nyti.ms/SmkNHa
caption: NULL

name: Why the Beaver Should Thank the Wolf
message: Op-Ed contributor Mary Ellen Hannibal writes, 'The rationale that eliminating the predator increases the prey is shortsighted and ignores larger food-web dynamics. A degraded ecosystem will be far less productive over all.'
description: Wolves and other predators have a powerful effect on the well-being of the ecosystems around them.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Jay-Z Comes Home to Repay a Debt to Brooklyn
message: Jay-Z returned to Brooklyn Friday night to perform a sold-out show in the new home of the Nets, the Barclays Center. See photos from the concert and read more at the link below.
description: The artist was at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn for the first show of a sold-out eight night run in the new rusty bunker that will house the Brooklyn Nets.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The College Rankings Racket
message: Op-Ed columnist Joe Nocera writes, 'The U.S. News & World Report’s annual college rankings came out earlier this month and — knock me over with a feather! — Harvard and Princeton were tied for first.'
description: The U.S. News & World Report’s annual list promotes status at the expense of affordable education.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Global Citizen Festival
message: Beginning at 4:00pm ET, watch the free live webcast of the Global Citizen Festival featuring performances by Neil Young with Crazy Horse, Foo Fighters and more on http://nyti.ms/StDEzl.
description: On Sept. 29 at 4:30 p.m. EST, watch a live video of Neil Young with Crazy Horse, Foo Fighters, The Black Keys and others in a charity concert to end world poverty.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Elite and Deft, Xi Aimed High Early in China
message: Quotation of the Day: 'I realized that this guy, who from his style of dress made him look like a lad from the canteen crew, was the new deputy party secretary.' - Wang Youhui, a local official, on his first impression of Xi Jinping, who is on the cusp of becoming China’s supreme leader.
description: An early move to rural China offers a window on the political savvy of Xi Jinping, who is on the cusp of taking over as China’s supreme leader.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Obamanomics: A Counterhistory
message: In the Sunday Review, David Leonhardt writes, 'We can never know for sure what the past four years would have been like if the administration and the Fed had been more worried about the economy. But my reading of the evidence — and some former Obama aides agree — points strongly to the idea that the misjudging of the downturn did affect policy and ultimately the economy.'
description: What could the administration have done to strengthen a weak recovery?
caption: nytimes.com

name: Supreme Court Faces Weighty Cases and a New Dynamic
message: The Supreme Court returns to the bench on Monday. The coming term will probably include major decisions on affirmative action in higher education admissions, same-sex marriage and a challenge to the heart of the Voting Rights Act of 1965. Those rulings could easily rival the last term’s as the most consequential in recent memory.
description: The new term will probably include major decisions on affirmative action in higher education admissions, same-sex marriage and a challenge to the heart of the Voting Rights Act of 1965.
caption: nytimes.com

name: A Trans-Atlantic Trip Turns Kafkaesque
message: Gary Shteyngart writes, 'Flight 121 from Paris to New York began on a clear autumn afternoon. It ended over 30 hours later. For those of us without miles, it is probably still going.'
description: American Airlines should no longer be flying across the Atlantic. It does not have the know-how or the equipment, and its employees have clearly lost interest in the endeavor.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Inside the Mind of Worry
message: 'Researchers in neuroscience, psychology, economics and other disciplines have made a range of discoveries about why human beings sometimes fear more than the evidence warrants, and sometimes less than the evidence warns. That science is worth reviewing at length. But one current issue offers a crash course in the most significant of these findings: the fear of vaccines, particularly vaccines for children,' writes David Ropeik in the Sunday Review.
description: The basic architecture of the brain ensures that we feel first and think second.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Seeing the Beauty in the Bronx
message: “It’s not Giverny — it’s the Bronx. But still, there’s beauty in the world.” - Daniel Hauben. Zoom in on our interactive feature to see the beauty in the Bronx as painted by Daniel Hauben.
description: Daniel Hauben, 56, a painter who grew up in the Bronx, infuses his scenes of the oft-maligned borough with a touch of whimsy.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The Inspiration Issue
message: What inspires you in your life and work? In the magazine’s Inspiration Issue, we tell you about the best books, movies, TV shows, music and art on the horizon, and the stories that led to their creation. Michael Chabon writes about how the O.J. Simpson verdict inspired “Telegraph Avenue,” Alicia Keys describes how she wrote the song “Girl on Fire,” Junot Díaz shares the artifacts that help him write and much more.
description: The creation stories behind the best movies, books, TV shows, music and plays on the horizon, featuring Alicia Keys, Michael Chabon, Quentin Tarantino, Al Pacino, Junot Díaz, Carrie Brownstein, Carly Rae Jepsen, Debra Winger, Patti LuPone and (a lot) more.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Proudly Bearing Elders’ Scars, Their Skin Says ‘Never Forget’
message: Quotation of the Day: 'We are moving from lived memory to historical memory. We’re at that transition, and this is sort of a brazen, in-your-face way of bridging it.' - Michael Berenbaum, a Holocaust scholar, on the practice of young Israelis getting tattoos of the numbers their elders were branded with at Nazi camps.
description: Some descendants of Holocaust survivors are having their concentration-camp numbers tattooed on their arms, a practice that provokes mixed reactions and a lot of conversation.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The Conservative Case for Obamacare
message: Op-Ed contributor  J. D. Kleinke writes, 'The architecture of the Affordable Care Act is based on conservative, not liberal, ideas about individual responsibility and the power of market forces.'
description: Transparency. Mobility. Choice. It’s Market Economics 101.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Challenging the Claims of Media Bias
message: Do you agree with David Carr that conservatives' cries of a liberal media bias is unfounded? You can subscribe to David Carr's public updates on Facebook here: http://www.facebook.com/davidcarrnyt
description: The mainstream media are frequently faulted as biased against conservative causes. But it seems a dubious notion when the ownership of the megaphone is increasingly up for grabs.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Payroll Tax Cut Unlikely to Survive Into Next Year
message: While Republicans and Democrats in Washington can't agree over most issues related to taxes, there seems to be one area where they don't disagree. The payroll tax holiday, which has provided the typical American family with $1,000 in additional income, will expire on Jan. 1. There is no push in Congress to extend it.What will your family cut back on when the payroll tax is restored to its earlier levels?
description: A tax break for 160 million wage earners, pushed last winter by the White House, now finds little support in Washington, as Congress struggles with deficits and turns its attention to the Bush-era income tax cuts.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Marriage Seen Through a Contract Lens
message: It may be time to acknowledge the harsh truth that nearly half of marriages in the United States end in divorce and many others are miserable, and consider something like a 20-year marriage contract.Do you think short term marriage contracts could prevent some of the pain of divorce?
description: It may be time to acknowledge the harsh truth that nearly half of marriages in the United States end in divorce and many others are miserable, and consider something like a 20-year marriage contract.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Barry Commoner Dies at 95
message: Look back at the life of Dr. Barry Commoner, a founder of modern ecology and one of its most provocative thinkers and mobilizers. His 4 informal rules of ecology were:Everything Is Connected to Everything Else. Everything Must Go Somewhere. Nature Knows Best. There Is No Such Thing as a Free Lunch.Dr. Commoner also sat for a 'Last Word' video for The New York Times: http://nyti.ms/STJCzw
description: Dr. Commoner, a Columbia- and Harvard-trained biologist, was a leader among a generation of scientist-activists who recognized the toxic consequences of America’s technology boom.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Wi-Fi Is Increasingly Essential for Airline Travelers
message: More and more, people expect constant connectivity. And as airlines race to make Wi-Fi available on all flights, the ability to stay online in the skies will only increase.Do you want to stay connected on a flight?
description: More and more, people expect constant connectivity. And as airlines race to make Wi-Fi available on all flights, the ability to stay online in the skies will only increase.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Seth MacFarlane Is to Host the Oscars
message: If you can’t beat ‘em, hire ‘em to host: Seth MacFarlane, the creator of 'The Family Guy' who voices many of its characters, has been selected to host the Oscars award ceremony next February. Do you think he'll make a good host?
description: The Oscars host next year will be Seth MacFarlane, the academy announced.
caption: artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com

name: The New York Times
message: New details have been revealed about the attack on a U.S. consulate in Libya on Sept. 11. American officials may have underestimated the risk to U.S. diplomats and other personnel in Benghazi.Read more here: http://nyti.ms/W9PK5jVisit our full interactive graphic to understand how the attack was carried out. The image pictured below is only a screenshot. Make sure you visit http://nyti.ms/SbH660 to see the complete timeline of the attack.
description: The assault on American diplomatic facilities in Benghazi, Libya, which the White House is now calling a terrorist attack, was moblike to start but became a sophisticated ambush. Read more: http://nyti.ms/UmYhz3.The American mission in Benghazi was attacked twice on the night of Sept. 11, 2012. Explore this interactive graphic (http://nyti.ms/SbH660) to track the events that evening that resulted in the deaths of Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens and three other Americans. (This is just a screenshot. Make sure you visit http://nyti.ms/SbH660 to see the complete interactive graphic.)
caption: NULL

name: Video: Presidential Debate Moments
message: President Obama and Mitt Romney will square off in their first presidential debate on Wednesday. Look back at some of the most memorable moments in modern debates with this video. What moments in presidential debates do you remember most vividly?
description: Sam Tanenhaus, editor of the Book Review, talks about some of the most memorable presidential debate moments of the televised era.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Hey, @SeattlePD: What’s the Latest?
message: Quotation of the Day: 'More and more people want to know what’s going on on their piece of the rock.' - John Diaz, chief of police in Seattle, which is providing crime reports in neighborhood Twitter accounts.
description: The Seattle Police Department has begun 51 hyper-local Twitter accounts to provide crime reports.
caption: nytimes.com

name: A Speed Limit for the Stock Market
message: Op-Ed contributor Roger Lowenstein writes, 'The purpose of financial markets, remember, is not to provide a forum for split-second trading. If you want to gamble, go to Las Vegas.'
description: The “liquidity” high-frequency trading provides is long past the point of being helpful.
caption: nytimes.com

name: MacArthur Fellows Named for 2012
message: What would you do with a no-strings-attached grant of $100,000 a year for the next five years? In the latest round of MacArthur grants, 23 people were surprised with just that.
description: Fields as diverse as teaching, ecology and filmmaking were represented among the winners of the latest round of MacArthur Fellows.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The Opening Statement
message: Op-Ed columnist David Brooks encourages Mitt Romney to run the last month of the campaign as himself, 'a nonideological guy running in an ideological age.' Would this make you more likely to vote for Romney?
description: Here is what Mitt Romney should say at the first debate this week.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Unforgettable Moments in Political Debates
message: From Richard Nixon's sweat to Rick Perry's 'Oops,' the debates have provided some memorable moments. Which is your favorite?
description: Twelve memorable moments from past debates that helped to define a candidate, for better or worse. Vote for your favorite clip.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Key Part of Voter ID Law in Pennsylvania Is Delayed for Election
message: For the presidential election, voters in Pennsylvania could be asked to produce the newly required photo IDs, but if they do not have them can still go ahead and vote.
description: A Pennsylvania judge delayed full implementation of a highly contested state law requiring strict photographic identification to vote in next month’s election.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Readers Won't Benefit if Times Bans the Term 'Illegal Immigrant'
message: After two weeks of research, Public Editor Margaret Sullivan says the term 'illegal immigrant,' which some readers have asked the Times to stop using, is 'clear and accurate.' (As public editor, Sullivan does not make Times style decisions.)
description: The public editor's judgment is not about immigration reform; it's about clarity and accuracy.
caption: publiceditor.blogs.nytimes.com

name: Shopping Sites Pay Contributors Who Drive Traffic to Retailers
message: Could endorsing a product on your Facebook page be worth real money? One site pays users an average of 14 cents for each click they send to participating retailers.
description: Social media shopping sites are offering payments to shoppers who post product links that drive Web traffic and sales to retailers.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Jeremy Lin, Back in Houston, Already Feels at Home
message: Jeremy Lin has the respect of his teammates and is feeling at home in Houston. “I had a lot of fun last year, and I’m having a lot of fun now.”
description: Jeremy Lin, who was a short-lived sensation with the Knicks, has fit right in on a rookie-rich Rockets team.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Jerry Seinfeld (Really!) Riffs About ... Something
message: Jerry Seinfeld wrote a letter to the editor. Really.
description: The comedian takes a television critic to task.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Voter ID Law Gutted for 2012 in Pennsylvania
message: Quotation of the Day: 'Every voter restriction that has been challenged this year has been either enjoined, blocked or weakened. It has been an extraordinary string of victories for those opposing these laws.' - Lawrence Norden, of the Brennan Center for Justice of the New York University School of Law.
description: A Pennsylvania ruling was the latest and most significant in a series of legal victories for those opposed to laws that they charge would limit access to polls in this presidential election.
caption: nytimes.com

name: What Mitt Should Tell the 47 Percent
message: Op-Ed columnist Ross Douthat writes, 'There’s one poll number that Mitt Romney should be most worried about. It’s not the tracking polls, or the RealClearPolitics polling average, or any of the usual measurements. It’s the percentage of Americans who believe that his policies will favor the rich over the poor and the middle class.'
description: On taxes, health care and Medicare reform, Romney should strike a more populist note.
caption: campaignstops.blogs.nytimes.com

name: Do Exercise Programs Help Children Stay Fit?
message: If structured classes and programs are not getting children to move more, what can be done to increase physical activity in the young?
description: Exercise programs during or after school did little to make young people more active, a new study found. So how can we get children to move more?
caption: well.blogs.nytimes.com

name: Unfriending Someone, Before Facebook
message: When it's time for a friendship to end, is it best to let that person know in person? Joyce Wadler, a columnist for the Booming series on middle age, remembers the straightforward methods her mother and grandmother used to break up with friends and relatives.Find more articles from Booming here: http://nyti.ms/QPyJwX
description: How much better things were 50 years ago, when a relationship went south and you knew why.
caption: nytimes.com

name: A Glimmer in the Vast Wasteland of Television
message: Describing the purpose of debates in the campaign for the presidency, Op-Ed contributor Newton N. Minow writes, 'The debates are one of the few features of our political campaigns that are still admired throughout the world.' Do you agree? Stay tuned to NYTimes.com and to our Facebook page this evening for coverage of tonight's debate between Mitt Romney and President Obama.
description: Despite a rocky history, the presidential debates are one place in the modern campaign — perhaps the only place — where the voter is treated with respect.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Stanley Tucci: Actor, Writer, Family Cook
message: “I didn’t go to school with a lunch bag,” actor Stanley Tucci recalls of realizing his family paid an unusually high degree of attention to food. “I went to school with a grocery bag.” Does your family have unusual mealtime rituals? Watch Mr. Tucci prepare a family feast that includes branzino, pizza, fettuccine, figs and prosciutto.
description: A love of food has shaped the actor Stanley Tucci’s life and career, in which cooking and eating seem to be ever present.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Before Obama and Romney Debate, a Review of Key Numbers
message: Numbers to listen for during tonight's presidential debate: 8.1 percent, $5 trillion, $3.80, 47 percent. Find out what these and others refer to and why the candidates might cite them in the article below.Find full coverage of tonight's debate beginning at 8:15 on http://www.nytimes.com and at http://www.facebook.com/nytimes
description: President Obama and Mitt Romney are poised to cite numbers, statistics and percentages to bolster their arguments in their first debate — but a few figures are not likely to come up at all.
caption: nytimes.com

name: What Romney, Obama’s Body Language Says to Voters
message: Since the first televised presidential debate, campaigns have been aware that voters may judge candidates as much by their appearance and gestures as by their words. Explore this interactive feature about the body language of Mitt Romney and President Obama, and what it conveys to voters. Then watch for the gestures of each in tonight's live coverage on http://nytimes.com  or on mobile at http://mobile.nytimes.com starting just after 8 p.m. ET.
description: An analysis of the signature gestures used by President Obama and Mitt Romney in their speeches and debates.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Live Updates From the Presidential Debate in Denver
message: Follow the debate with live video, updates and  fact-checking and stay tuned after for expert analysis by New York Times politics staff. Coverage is also available on our mobile apps and http://mobile.nytimes.com
description: Updates and analysis from New York Times reporters on the first debate between Mitt Romney and President Obama.
caption: elections.nytimes.com

name: Timeline Photos
message: We're fact-checking the debates in real time, including Mitt Romney's claim that 23 million people are out of work. Follow our live blog for more fact-checking and coverage: http://nyti.ms/PxbNhE
description: NULL
caption: NULL

name: Miguel Cabrera Wins Baseball’s Triple Crown
message: A monumental moment in baseball history: Miguel Cabrera of the Detroit Tigers has won the game's triple crown by simultaneously leading the American League in home runs, batting average and runs batted in. He is the first player to have reached this milestone since Carl Yastrzemski did so in 1967.
description: Miguel Cabrera was always a prodigy, and now he has become the first baseball player to sweep baseball’s triple crown categories in almost half a century.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Full Debate: Mitt Romney v. Barack Obama 10/3/12
message: Watch the full debate between Barack Obama and Mitt Romney. (Don't know what to believe? We fact-checked the debate here: http://nyti.ms/WlYGVk)
description: First presidential debate bewteen Barack Omama and Mitt Romney in the run up to the general election in November.
caption: youtube.com

name: Drought Leaves Cracks in Way of Life
message: Quotation of the Day: 'You probably can’t print our mood.' - Dallis Basel, a sheep rancher in South Dakota, on the effects of the drought.
description: Lost amid the withered crops and dehydrated cattle that symbolize the most widespread drought in decades has been the toll on families that depend on farming.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Cool Hand Barry
message: Op-Ed columnist Charles M. Blow writes, 'There are two more chances for the president to change tactics, or at least to show up to the debates energized and nimble: President Xanax just doesn’t cut it.'
description: Obama's debate strategy was misguided. His tactics were ineffective. He must solve both problems before round two.
caption: campaignstops.blogs.nytimes.com

name: Breaking Down the First Presidential Debate
message: Browse and watch 18 highlights from last night's debate, paired with our reporters' fact-checks of statements made by the candidates. And tell us: Which of these moments do you think was the most key for Obama or Romney?
description: Follow along with this interactive replay of the debate, using fact checks and graphics take a closer look at the candidates’ assertions and attacks.
caption: nytimes.com

name: After Debate, a Harsh Light Falls on Jim Lehrer
message: Jim Lehrer, the longtime PBS news anchor, has moderated 11 presidential debates during his career.  Many commentators have criticized the job he did during President Obama and Mitt Romney's first debate, but he has consistently said that his job as moderator is to get out of the way and let the candidates talk.How would you rate Mr. Lehrer's moderation effort last night?
description: Democrats in particular were critical of the light touch used by the moderator Jim Lehrer.
caption: nytimes.com

name: (Step)-Family Trees With Tangled Branches
message: Do you invite your ex-stepsister to your wedding, given that you shared a bunk bed with her for seven formative years? What, if anything, do you call your ex-stepgrandmother? For thousands of people, such questions are not hypothetical.Have divorce or other changes to family dynamics changed your connection to a step-relative?
description: When step-relatives become former step-relatives, questions emerge that can require a whiteboard to figure out.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Unfriending Someone, Before Facebook
message: Is unfriending a person on Facebook the right way to sever a relationship?
description: How much better things were 50 years ago, when a relationship went south and you knew why.
caption: nytimes.com

name: In Myanmar's Makeover, Politics Is Just the Beginning
message: Myanmar's changes are going beyond its political opening. The country has begun to search for a national identity defined by its people, not the one imposed by military governments.
description: Myanmar has begun to search for a national identity defined by its people, not the cloistered vision imposed by military governments that took power in 1962 and only relinquished control last year.
caption: nytimes.com

name: As Iran’s Currency Keeps Tumbling, Anxiety Is Rising
message: Quotation of the Day: 'As I was gathering my money, the man received a phone call. When he hung up he told me prices had just gone up by 10 percent. Of course I paid. God knows how much it will cost tomorrow.' - Abbbas Sharabi, a retired factory guard in Tehran, on buying rice.
description: In the Iranian capital, all anyone can talk about is the rial, and how lives have been turned upside down during a week in which the currency’s value plunged by 40 percent.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Jobless Rate Falls to 7.8%, Lowest Since January 2009
message: The U.S. economy added 114,000 jobs in September, and the jobs reports of July and August were revised upward from what had previously been reported.Unemployment is now at its lowest rate since January 2009. Has the jobs picture improved where you live?
description: While employers added only a modest number of jobs, the unemployment rate dropped below 8 percent for the first time in the Obama presidency.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Moving Beyond Affirmative Action
message: Op-Ed contributor Thomas J. Espenshade writes, 'Race-based affirmative action has been a woefully inadequate weapon in the arsenal against inequality.'
description: A Supreme Court ruling against the University of Texas might put ethnic and racial diversity on college campuses on a firmer footing for the long term.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Speedy Airport Security: Should You Apply?
message: If you've stood in an airport security line shoeless, beltless, clutching a Ziploc bag and inching grimly toward a full body scanner, it might be time to apply for for the U.S. Customs and Border Protection’s Global Entry program. How much would you to pay to skip past most airport security?
description: Programs that accelerate customs and security screening are catching on with travelers. But are they right for you? Here are answers to some common questions.
caption: travel.nytimes.com

name: 10 Pear Salad Recipes
message: Mark Bittman shares 10 pear salad recipes to make you forget about apples. Explore the recipes at the link below and read the related article here: http://nyti.ms/OHL3k2
description: 10 pear salads to make you forget about apples. For a while, at least.
caption: nytimes.com

name: For a Mother, Grief and Anger After the Police Fatally Shoot Her Son
message: While speeding home on Thursday at about 5:15 a.m, Noel Polanco was forced to stop and shot by a detective. The police have not been able to provide an explanation about what prompted Detective Hamdy to fire his gun.
description: Cecilia Reyes was joined by relatives and friends as she grieved for her son, Noel Polanco, 22, who was shot during a traffic stop in Queens.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Romney’s Sick Joke
message: Op-Ed columnist Paul Krugman writes, 'The fact is that Mr. Romney tried to mislead the public, and he shouldn’t be allowed to get away with it.'
description: Mitt Romney’s claim that pre-existing conditions are covered under his health plan was his biggest of many misleading statements in Wednesday’s debate.
caption: nytimes.com

name: It’s Snowing in Minnesota! Yes, October Is Early for That
message: Summer isn't over in some parts of the United States. But up in Minnesota and parts of North Dakota, a foot of snow fell in a rare early October storm.Are you experiencing any unseasonable weather where you live?
description: In the northern Minnesota town of Roseau, 14 inches of snow fell. Meteorologists say snowfall will be above normal this winter in an arc of the country stretching from Minnesota to New York.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Letting Patients Read the Doctor's Notes
message: Have you ever seen your medical records?
description: In a one-year trial, patients who were allowed to read all the notes their doctors wrote about them in their medical charts were enthusiastic. Surprisingly, so were most of their doctors.
caption: well.blogs.nytimes.com

name: In a State of Sweaty Agitation in Steamy Florida
message: A. O. Scott writes that 'The Paper Boy' is 'a domestic melodrama, a Southern Gothic, a legal thriller, a coming-of-age-story, a high-toned sexploitation picture and an earnest lesson in journalistic ethics and race relations' all at once. Will you see any movies this weekend? Watch a 2-minute discussion with the director, Lee Daniels, at the link below.
description: “The Paperboy,” a tangled and steamy drama directed by Lee Daniels, stars Nicole Kidman as a woman whose fiancé, played by John Cusack, is an alligator hunter on death row.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Healthier School Lunches Face Student Rejection
message: Quotation of the Day: 'Before, there was no taste and no flavor. Now there's no taste, no flavor and it's healthy, which makes it taste even worse.'  — Malik Barrows, a senior at Automotive High School in Brooklyn, N.Y., on school lunches.
description: Students get more fruits and vegetables under new nutritional requirements for public school lunches, but many children just toss them away.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Jobs Report: Cooked or Correct?
message: In Opinion, Joe Nocera writes, 'Whether the Republicans like it or not, the economy is slowly getting better.' What's your take on the new jobs report numbers?
description: The latest government employment report, a month from Election Day, created quite a stir.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Helping a Child to Come Out
message: Some parents know and accept that their sons or daughters are gay or lesbian long before their children are comfortable talking about it. Should parents wait for their kids to come to terms with their sexual orientation before initiating a discussion about it?
description: Wider acceptance of gays and lesbians have made the process of coming out less stigmatizing for many children, but it remains a difficult process.
caption: nytimes.com

name: New Zealand’s Hobbit Trail
message: How die-hard of a 'Hobbit' fan are you? Enough to travel all the way to Hobbiton, the place in remotest New Zealand where the forthcoming 'Hobbit' movies were filmed? 'Like' Travel | The New York Times for more inspiration on unusual pilgrimages: http://nyti.ms/Q44LDr
description: With the first of three Hobbit movies about to be released, New Zealand is preparing for the next wave of Tolkien tourists, from the hills of the Shire to the peaks of Mordor.
caption: travel.nytimes.com

name: Shopping List: Tuna, Detergent, a Warhol
message: Would you buy a piece of fine art from Costco?
description: Costco, the giant discount retailer, is returning to the art market after a six-year hiatus prompted by the sale of two disputed Picasso drawings online.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Timeline Photos
message: Venezuelans go to the polls on Sunday to choose between President Hugo Chávez, seen here delivering a speech in Guarenas, and his challenger, Henrique Capriles Radonski. (Photo: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times) Our latest report on the Venezuelan presidential election: http://nyti.ms/VopxChPhotographs of the two campaigns and their supporters: http://nyti.ms/QKRelP
description: NULL
caption: NULL

name: Citing U.S. Fears, Arab Allies Limit Syrian Rebel Aid
message: Quotation of the Day: 'You can give the rebels AKs, but you can’t stop the Syrian regime’s military with AKs.' - Khalid Al-Attiyah, a Qatari official, on Syrian rebels pleas for heavier weapons, an idea that has been resisted by the United States government.
description: Officials in Saudi Arabia and Qatar said they were withholding heavier weapons in part because of worries by the United States that they could end up in the hands of terrorists.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Why Women Hide Their Pregnancies
message: Do you know women who worried about being discriminated against by their bosses during their pregnancies? Have you had this experience yourself?
description: In an economy where women now make up half the work force, we’re going to have to address the treatment of pregnant employees more systemically.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Who Made That Escape Key?
message: 'There's something nice about having a get-me-the-hell-out-of-here key,' says Bob Bemer, the I.B.M. programmer who invented the escape key on computer keyboards in 1960. Do you feel a fondness for the ESC button on your keyboard or is it something you never use anymore? For the complete story on how the ESC came to be, click below.
description: The button that stands between machine and master.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Timeline Photos
message: Would allowing for taller skyscrapers enhance or disrupt your experience of Midtown Manhattan? http://nyti.ms/Q4t6b7A rezoning plan proposed by Mayor Bloomberg for the area from 39th Street to 57th Street on the East Side would permit the construction of state-of-the-art towers even taller than the 59-story MetLife Building or the 77-story Chrysler Building, but the plan has many critics.  (Photo: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)
description: NULL
caption: NULL

name: They Work Long Hours, but What About Results?
message: Limit meetings; reduce reading; write faster. Those are three of the suggestions Robert Pozen of Harvard Business School and the Brookings Institution makes in this article on how to improve your efficiency at work. What are your own strategies for accomplishing your work in less time?
description: Often, professionals are judged by the amount of time they spend at the office. But that gauge can be at odds with workplace efficiency.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Marijuana Only for the Sick? A Farce, Some Angelenos Say
message: Quotation of the Day: 'I felt we needed a medical situation with respect, not with all kinds of music going, tattoos and piercings in the face.' - Yamileth Bolanos, owner of a marijuana dispensary in Los Angeles, on a crackdown on California’s medical marijuana industry.
description: While the federal government cracks down on dispensaries of medical marijuana, Los Angeles repealed a recent ban on them.
caption: nytimes.com

name: How to Die
message: Op-Ed columnist Bill Keller writes, 'Here in the United States, nothing bedevils our discussion of health care like the question of when and how to withhold it.'
description: A death in the family brings some lessons about how we can best approach our final days.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Two Paths Through Dartmouth Meet in a U.S. Senate Race
message: Dartmouth College began to admit women in 1972, but they were not universally welcomed. Women were called cohogs, rather than coeds, and threatened with menacing letters. Two alumnae of this era, Senator Kirsten Gillibrand and Wendy E. Long are running against each other for the United States Senate in New York, with sharply different political views and understandings of the world.
description: Senator Kirsten Gillibrand of New York and Wendy Long, her Republican challenger, went to Dartmouth College amid the hostility that followed the admission of women.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Timeline Photos
message: When Lorne Michaels couldn't get a candidate to appear on this Saturday's episode of Saturday Night Live, he put in a call to Big Bird. The cast didn't receive a final version of the script until two hours before filming would begin, but they managed to salvage humor from a presidential debate that seemingly lacked any. (Photo: Karsten Moran for The New York Times)See more behind-the-scenes photos and read about the taping here: http://nyti.ms/QZGywF
description: NULL
caption: NULL

name: Truth About Jobs
