'Machias Seal Island and nearby North Rock are the only pieces of land that the two countries both claim after more than 230 years of vigorous and sometimes violent border-making between them,' writes Op-Ed contributor Stephen R. Kelly.
description: The United States and Canada need to fix their final territorial dispute.
caption: nytimes.com

name: 100 Notable Books of 2012
message: In your opinion, what was the best book published in 2012? Here's The Book Review's annual list of 100 notable books. Did your favorite make the list?
description: The Book Review’s annual list.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Gay ‘Conversion Therapy’ Faces Tests in Courts
message: “It becomes fraudulent, even cruel. To say that if you really want to change you could — that’s an awful thing to tell somebody.” -  Michael Ferguson, who sought help battling his homosexuality from New Jersey's Jonah counseling center in 2008.
description: Methods that claim to help men overcome unwanted same-sex attractions are being legally challenged in New Jersey and California.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Congressional Proposal Could Create 'Bubble' in Tax Code
message: On the FiveThirtyEight blog, Nate Silver explains how one Congressional proposal to create a 'tax bubble,' which places the heaviest tax burden on the somewhat wealthy as opposed to the very wealthy, is 'hard to defend from the standpoint of rational public policy.'Follow all the updates on the so-called fiscal cliff and the options the parties are considering: http://nyti.ms/WT6xg7
description: One proposal being floated as an alternative to raising the top marginal rate would place its heaviest tax burden on the somewhat wealthy as opposed to the very wealthy.
caption: fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com

name: After Losing an Arm in War, the Hard Road Back
message: After the explosion in Afghanistan, Cpl. Sebastian Gallegos awoke to see the October sun glinting through the water, an image so lovely he thought he was dreaming. Then something caught his eye, yanking him back to grim awareness: an arm, bobbing near the surface. Two years later, the corporal is adjusting to his prosthetic upper limb, a $110,000 robotic device with an electronic motor and sensors able to read signals from his brain.
description: After losing his arm in an I.E.D. explosion in Afghanistan, Cpl. Sebastian Gallegos has adjusted to his prosthetic limb. Related Article: http://nyti.ms/WsHl...
caption: youtube.com

name: City Is Amassing Trove of Cellphone Logs
message: When a cellphone is reported stolen in New York, the Police Department routinely subpoenas the phone’s call records, from the day of the theft onward. The logic is simple: If a thief uses the phone, a list of incoming and outgoing calls could lead to the suspect. But in the process, the Police Department has quietly amassed a trove of telephone logs, all obtained without a court order, that could conceivably be used for any investigative purpose.
description: Subpoenas for call records of stolen cellphones have allowed the Police Department to store the information of thousands of victims a year.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Marvin Miller, Union Leader Who Changed Baseball, Dies at 95
message: Look back at the life and work of Marvin Miller who secured his place on baseball's Mount Rushmore by forging one of the strongest unions in America, creating a model for those in basketball, football and hockey. When Mr. Miller was named executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association in 1966, club owners ruled much as they had since the 19th century. The reserve clause bound players to their teams for as long as the owners wanted them, leaving them with little bargaining power. If Mr. Miller had one overarching achievement, it was to persuade professional athletes to cast aside the paternalism of the owners and to emerge as economic forces in their own right, armed with often immense bargaining power.
description: By building the major league baseball players union into a force that revolutionized the game, Mr. Miller became one of the most influential figures in the sport’s history.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Facebook Gifts Urges Users to Shop While They Share
message: What do you think about Facebook’s hope that you'll buy gifts for your friends through the site using your credit cards?
description: Facebook has started an online gift service, hoping that the moneymaking potential of social gift giving will please its Wall Street investors.
caption: nytimes.com

name: My Secretary of State
message: 'Education is now the key to sustainable power. To have a secretary of state who is one of the world’s leading authorities on education, well, everyone would want to talk to him,' writes Thomas L. Friedman in his Op-Ed column nominating the current education secretary Arne Duncan to be the next secretary of state.
description: Here’s a case for making Arne Duncan the secretary of state in President Obama’s second term. It actually makes sense when you think about it.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Kim Jong-un Seems to Get a New Title: Heartthrob
message: Did the Chinese Communist Party’s official mouthpiece, the People's Daily, fall for an Onion parody naming Kim Jong-un the 'Sexiest Man Alive for 2012'?  Or did someone at People’s Daily create the slide show with a subversive wink?
description: It was unclear whether the People’s Daily in China had fallen for an Onion parody naming the North Korean ruler the “Sexiest Man Alive for 2012.”
caption: nytimes.com

name: California Finds Economic Gloom Starting to Lift
message: With evidence of job growth, a resurgent housing market and rising spirits, California, a state that was among the worst hit by the recession, is showing signs of a rebound.
description: After nearly five years of brutal economic decline, government retrenchment and a widespread loss of confidence in its future, California is showing the first signs of a rebound.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Sunni Leaders Gaining Clout in Mideast
message: The United States is left somewhat wary about the rising Sunni Muslim alliance of Egypt, Qatar and Turkey. While Sunni leaders want a more quiet, stable Middle East and are willing to work with Washington, they also promote a radical religious-based ideology that has fueled anti-Western sentiment around the region.
description: The United States is left somewhat wary about the rising Sunni Muslim alliance of Egypt, Qatar and Turkey and its potential for anti-Western sentiment.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The Argument Against Pound-Foolish Travel
message: Have you traveled with someone who put the budget before the travel? Describe the cheapest traveler you've ever gone on tour with below. What were the high and low points of the trip?
description: One of the hardest parts of traveling on a shoestring is figuring out when not to save money. I call it Pound-Foolish Travel.
caption: frugaltraveler.blogs.nytimes.com

name: Can a Jellyfish Unlock the Secret of Immortality?
message: Want to live forever? This jellyfish, which can age in reverse at any stage of its development, appears to debunk the most fundamental law of the natural world—you are born, and then you die.
description: The little creature of the sea that appears to debunk the most fundamental law of the natural world — you are born, and then you die.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Who Needs an Oven? Just Bury Your Beans
message: Discover what chef Chris Schlesinger calls his “tricked-out, souped-up, chef’s style” bean hole. (If your first reaction is to giggle, you're not alone. That's how this article's author John Willoughby first responded too.)
description: The right pot, a small pit, some rocks and a lot of time combine to make baked beans with a big flavor payoff.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Servicewomen File Suit Over Direct Combat Ban
message: Do you think military servicewomen should be able to serve in direct combat jobs? Four military servicewomen, who all served tours in Afghanistan or Iraq, filed a federal lawsuit on Tuesday seeking to end the Pentagon’s ban on women serving in direct combat jobs.
description: Four military servicewomen, who all served tours in Afghanistan or Iraq, filed a federal lawsuit seeking to end the Pentagon’s ban on women serving in direct combat jobs.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Hunger in Plain Sight
message: “It seems absurd to have to say it, but no one in this country should go hungry,” Mark Bittman writes in Opinion. He cites that 46 million Americans currently receive government assistance to buy food, though many more are eligible, and others turn to food banks, which have been hit hard by cutbacks.
description: One in eight Americans get government assistance to buy food, yet many more are eligible.
caption: opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com

name: The New York Times
message: Damon Winter visited Ethiopia's Simien Mountains last November and captured some stunning photos of the gelada. Browse his photos: http://nyti.ms/StNS62. The gelada are sometimes called bleeding heart baboons because of a red patch on the chest of the males.
description: Times photographer Damon Winter describes watching geladas in Ethiopia do a 'delicate dance' before being encircled by them: http://nyti.ms/StNS62 (Credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times)
caption: NULL

name: Spotted (and Striped): The Runaway Zebra of Staten Island
message: Meet the runaway zebra of Staten Island.
description: A zebra and a horse, said to be fugitives from a petting zoo, were seen trotting down Victory Boulevard on Wednesday morning.
caption: cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com

name: Despite Powerball Odds, a Mad Rush to the Registers
message: How would you react if you won $550 million? What would you do with the winnings? Do you regularly buy lottery tickets? Did you buy a ticket for today's Powerball drawing?
description: Across the country, Americans lined up for a chance to win a $550 million Powerball jackpot, the second-largest lottery jackpot in United States history.
caption: nytimes.com

name: U.S. Weighs Bolder Effort to Intervene in Syria’s Conflict
message: Quotation of the Day: 'The administration has figured out that if they don’t start doing something, the war will be over and they won’t have any influence over the combat forces on the ground.' - Jeffrey White, a former Defense Intelligence Agency intelligence officer and specialist on the Syria military.
description: The Obama administration is considering alternatives to help push out President Bashar al-Assad, including providing arms to opposition fighters, according to government officials.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Photo of Officer Giving Boots to Barefoot Man Warms Hearts All Over Web
message: On a cold November night in Times Square, NYPD's Officer Lawrence DePrimo encountered an older, barefooted homeless man. The officer disappeared for a moment, then returned with a new pair of boots, and knelt to help the man put them on. Read the story behind this act of kindness.
description: A New York police officer’s act of kindness to a homeless man in Times Square has reverberated on the Web.
caption: nytimes.com

name: British Press Needs New Regulator, Report Says
message: A major inquiry into the standards of British media triggered by a phone hacking scandal delivered an excoriating critique on Thursday, calling for tighter self-regulation underpinned by law.“The ball moves back into the politicians’ court,” Lord Justice Sir Brian Leveson said, referring to what form new and tighter regulations should take. “They must now decide who guards the guardians.”
description: A major inquiry triggered by Britain’s phone hacking scandal singled out Rupert Murdoch’s defunct tabloid The News of the World for specific criticism but offered an excoriating critique of the press as a whole.
caption: nytimes.com

name: For Obama and Romney, Lunch at the White House
message: If you could join President Obama and Mitt Romney for lunch today, what questions would you ask them?
description: Making good on an election-night pledge, President Obama plans to have lunch with his one-time Republican rival, Mitt Romney, at the White House on Thursday.
caption: thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com

name: With Focus on Talking Points, Benghazi Attack’s Big Issues Fade
message: Four pallid sentences that intelligence analysts cautiously delivered after the Benghazi killings are the unlikely center of a quintessential Washington drama. It is these talking points, rather than important questions about the lethal attack, that could decide the fate of a leading candidate for secretary of state, Susan E. Rice.
description: The parsing of four sentences, rather than important questions about the Benghazi killings, could decide the fate of a leading candidate for secretary of state, Susan E. Rice.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The New York Times
message: A pair of bras landed on the stage and Justin Bieber was unfazed. Jon Caramanica takes a look at 'the post-boy, not-quite-man pop star' who had the tiny kids, the preteens, the teenagers and even a few moms shrieking in New York last night. Read more: http://nyti.ms/V6goJi
description: Justin Bieber performed on Wednesday at Madison Square Garden in New York. Read our review of the show: http://nyti.ms/V6goJi (Photo by Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)
caption: NULL

name: In Drive to Unionize, Fast-Food Workers Walk Off the Job
message: Fast-food workers at several restaurants in New York walked off the job on Thursday, firing the first salvo in what workplace experts say is the biggest effort to unionize fast-food workers ever undertaken in the United States.
description: Labor experts said the campaign, named Fast Food Forward, faced a daunting challenge in seeking to raise wages to $15 an hour.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Law School Is Worth the Money
message: 'I’m a law dean, and I’m proud. And I think it’s time to stop the nonsense,' writes Op-Ed contributor and the dean of Case Western Reserve University’s law school, Lawrence E. Mitchell. Read his argument for the importance of a law school education.
description: Stop the relentless attacks on law school. There are jobs, and they pay well.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Another Shooting May Test Florida Law
message: In what could become another test of Florida’s broad self-defense law, a software developer charged with killing a Jacksonville teenager said he fired his gun only after he was threatened with a shotgun. The case has drawn parallels to the Trayvon Martin shooting because of the age and race of the victim, the fact that no weapon associated with the victim has been found, and the defendant’s self-defense claim.
description: After a dispute in Jacksonville turns fatal, Florida’s law about the use of deadly force in self-defense is likely to face renewed scrutiny.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The World Catches Up to Yoko Ono
message: Yoko Ono, almost 80, is still fighting world hunger and coming out with new albums. Now, she’s also designing men’s wear. One piece is “a plexi-necklace you wear with two bells attached and it’s placed where your breasts might be,” described Humberto Leon of Opening Ceremony, for which she is designing. “And inscribed underneath it says, ‘Ring for your mommy.’”
description: The artist is now designing men’s wear, accepting awards (and giving them) and, of course, coming out with a new album.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Ignoring the Science on Mammograms
message: Are doctors and patients ignoring the science of mammograms? “For years now, doctors like myself have known that screening mammography doesn’t save lives, or else saves so few that the harms far outweigh the benefits,” writes Dr. David Newman on the Well blog. Early detection “has, ironically, failed (ovarian, prostate cancer) as often as it has succeeded (cervical cancer, perhaps colon cancer).”
description: Despite years of data challenging the effectiveness of mammograms, why do doctors and patients continue to ignore the science?
caption: well.blogs.nytimes.com

name: Fiscal Talks in Congress Seem to Reach Impasse
message: The Treasury Secretary, Timothy Geithner, presented Speaker John Boehner today with a proposal to avert the fiscal cliff with $1.6 trillion in tax hikes over 10 years and other measures. The proposal was short on detailed spending cuts and seemed likely to face strong Republican resistance.Keep up with the federal budget talks on the NYT's debt reckoning interactive. http://nyti.ms/Tu21PI
description: House Republicans said a proposal by Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner to the House speaker, John A. Boehner,  was loaded with Democratic priorities and short on detailed cuts.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Palestine Wins Status of State in Vote by U.N. Assembly
message: More than 130 countries voted on Thursday to grant Palestine the upgraded status of nonmember state in the United Nations, a stinging defeat for Israel and the United States and a boost for President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority, who was weakened by the recent eight days of fighting in Gaza.
description: After failing to head off a vote in the United Nations on Thursday that would upgrade the Palestinian Authority’s status, the United States and Israel are looking ahead to how they can contain the damage from the approval.
caption: nytimes.com

name: U.N. Assembly, in Blow to U.S., Elevates Status of Palestine
message: Quotation of the Day: 'The General Assembly is called upon today to issue a birth certificate of the reality of the state of Palestine.' - Mahmoud Abbas, President of the Palestinian Authority, before a vote granting Palestine the upgraded status of nonmember observer state at the United Nations.
description: More than 130 countries voted to grant Palestine recognition as a nonmember observer state, in a stinging defeat for Israel and the United States and a boost for President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The New York Times
message: What is fair? As a country that spends more than it collects in taxes, are we asking the right taxpayers to pay the right amounts? Watch our video report: http://nyti.ms/11a7KA6.Despite their complaints, most Americans in 2010 paid far less in total taxes — federal, state and local — than they would have paid 30 years ago, according to an analysis by The Times. Read more: http://nyti.ms/SkcZs7.
description: Visit http://nyti.ms/Uwiypx to compare how much Americans paid in federal, state and local taxes over the past three decades. (Credit: The New York Times
caption: NULL

name: Class Wars of 2012
message: Those who voted for Mitt Romney, and lost, “are now trying to win by stealth—in the name of fiscal responsibility—the ground they failed to gain in the open election,” Paul Krugman writes in Opinion. “The class war is still on, this time with an added dose of deception.”
description: The same people who bet big on Mitt Romney, and lost, are now trying to win by stealth the ground they failed to gain in the election.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Israel Moves to Expand Settlements in East Jerusalem
message: On Thursday night Israel took steps toward building housing in a controversial area of East Jerusalem known as E1, where Jewish settlement activity has long been seen as the death knell for a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
description: The move toward building housing in a controversial area, coming immediately after the Palestinians won observer state status in the United Nations, was widely seen as punishment.
caption: nytimes.com

name: 10 Best Books of 2012
message: How many books have you read from The New York Times Book Review's '10 Best Books of 2012' list? Do you think the editors made the right selections? Would you add or remove any books?
description: The year’s best books, selected by the editors of The New York Times Book Review.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The New York Times
message: Is the Grand Canyon really old, or really, really old? Scientists extend their debate: http://nyti.ms/TydEaP
description: New research suggests that the Grand Canyon is about 70 million years old, but the prevailing view is that it is much younger: http://nyti.ms/TydEaP (Credit: Richard Perry/ The New York Times)
caption: NULL

name: Under One Roof, Building for Extended Families
message: How many generations of your family live under your roof? With more than 50 million Americans in multigenerational households—boomer couples living with their boomerang children and aging parents—major homebuilders are designing flexible layouts.
description: Multigenerational living, a throwback to the past, is a growing trend in the struggling economy, and major homebuilders are designing flexible layouts.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Ethnic Hatred Tears Apart a Region of Myanmar
message: Violence in western Myanmar — where clashes have left at least 167 people dead and 100,000 people homeless, most of them Muslims — has set off an exodus that some human rights groups condemn as ethnic cleansing.
description: In western Myanmar, clashes have left at least 167 people dead and 100,000 people homeless, most of them Muslims.
caption: nytimes.com

name: A Closely Guarded Secret: When the Camels Go for a Walk
message: Word has spread that the three camels performing in a Christmas show in Manhattan take morning constitutionals along 51st Street, though representatives of the theater seem to regard this pleasant fact as a national security secret.
description: Three camels performing in a Christmas Nativity scene take a break every morning in Midtown, but the routine is kept under wraps.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Change Comes to Playground Funny Papers
message: Where did you go Bazooka Joe? Bazooka bubble gum, which has suffered from sales declines, will overhaul its brand image for a new generation of chewers. What adults may remember best about the brand—the tiny comic strips that have wrapped each piece of gum since 1953—is disappearing.
description: With sales declining, Bazooka bubble gum will overhaul its brand for a new generation of chewers, including discontinuing the comic strips that have wrapped its product since 1953.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Think Like a Doctor: The Circus Trainer's Headache
message: Can you solve the case of an animal trainer who develops an excruciating headache after a run-in with a zebra?
description: Can you solve the mystery of a circus trainer who had a run-in with a zebra?
caption: well.blogs.nytimes.com

name: The Awards Season Starts for Movies
message: What's your pick for best picture this year? That's right. It's awards season and The Carpetbagger is back to report on the news and the nonsense of the Golden Globes, the Oscars and more. Go to http://nyti.ms/11cs1VC and see our readers' early picks for best picture.
description: The awards season begins for movies, with a wide range of favorite films.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Dream Act Gives Young Immigrants a Political Voice
message: Quotation of the Day: 'People are not going to hug the president right now. They are waiting for him to take some action.' – Carlos Saavedra, national coordinator of United We Dream, on a rejuvenated push for among the young for immigration reform.
description: A group that had worked effectively but largely under the radar to advance the prospects of undocumented youths learns to be more comfortable in the spotlight.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The Monster of Monticello
message: In the Opinion Pages, Paul Finkelman examines what he calls 'the ugly truth' about Thomas Jefferson. Read why the Op-Ed contributor calls the third president of the United States 'a creepy, brutal hypocrite.'
description: The ugly truth about our slave-owning third president.
caption: nytimes.com

name: A Hospital War Reflects a Bind for Doctors in the U.S.
message: Across the United States, doctors who sold their practices to hospitals and signed on as employees describe growing pressure to meet the financial goals of their new employers — often by performing unnecessary tests and procedures or by admitting patients who do not need a hospital stay.
description: As more physicians sell their practices to hospitals, they describe pressure to meet the financial goals of their new employers — often by performing unnecessary tests or by admitting patients who do not need a hospital stay.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Test-Flying the Boeing 787 Dreamliner
message: How would you improve airplane travel? See inside 'the plane of the future,' Boeing's new 787 Dreamliner.
description: Big windows, power for smartphones and even a crowd-pleasing toilet are all part of the Dreamliner experience, as the author discovered on the plane’s first North American charter.
caption: travel.nytimes.com

name: The New York Times
message: “Matisse: In Search of True Painting” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is 'one of the most thrillingly instructive exhibitions about this painter, or painting in general, that you may ever see,' writes New York Times art critic Roberta Smith. Read her full review: http://nyti.ms/SC1VX6.
description: The rigorous yet unfettered evolution of the French modernist Henri Matisse (1869-1954) is the subject of a new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. From left, “Le Luxe I” (1907), “Le Luxe II” (1907-08) and a drawing for “Le Luxe” (1907): http://nyti.ms/SC1VX6 (Photo Credit: Librado Romero/The New York Times)
caption: NULL

name: Timeline Photos
message: Everything is bigger in Texas, including the business incentives offered by the state, counties and cities. Explore what kind of incentives your state is extending to businesses to open shop near you: http://nyti.ms/TvdlLgThe New York Times spent 10 months investigating business incentives awarded by hundreds of cities, counties and states. States, cities and counties are giving up more than $80 billion a year to attract or keep companies and the jobs they provide. But officials and governments rarely track how many jobs follow, and many do not know the value of all their awards.Read the first installment in 'The United States of Subsidies' (http://nyti.ms/U9CD0h), our series examining business incentives and how they impact jobs and local economies.
description: NULL
caption: NULL

name: The Lives They Loved: Share Your Photos
message: Do you have a loved one who passed away this year? Share a photo and story about that person's life on the page linked here: http://nyti.ms/TvsIDv. Your photo may be featured online or in the printed 'The Lives They Lived' issue of The New York Times Magazine. You can browse readers' submissions from 2011 here: http://nyti.ms/Tvtdxh
description: For our coming The Lives They Lived issue, an annual celebration of some of the most intriguing people who have died over the past year, we are inviting you to contribute a photograph that illustrates a story from the life of someone close to you who passed away in 2012. It could be a wedding snapsh...
caption: submit.nytimes.com

name: With Bill Murray, Just Take the Trip
message: Bill Murray has become 'the folkloric equivalent of a leprechaun or fairy godparent, popping up at unpredictable yet opportune moments.' Read Dave Itzkoff's interview with Bill Murray and see the free-form actor's carefree philosophy in action.
description: Bill Murray, the free-form actor who’s starring as Franklin D. Roosevelt in the coming film “Hyde Park on Hudson,” takes an interviewer on an adventure.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Barefoot, Homeless Man Says He’s Grateful for Boots
message: The story of a police officer in New York City buying a pair of boots for a barefoot homeless man on a cold night has traveled around the world.Jeffrey Hillman, 54, is the man he helped. Mr. Hillman is barefoot again. He said he hid the boots because of their value.'I could lose my life,” he said.During the interview he also said, 'I want to thank everyone that got onto this thing. I want to thank them from the bottom of my heart. It meant a lot to me. And to the officer, first and foremost.”
description: Officer Lawrence DePrimo received news coverage for his generosity, but little was known about the man he helped, who in an interview on Sunday gave his name as Jeffrey Hillman.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Collaboration in Gaza Leads to Grisly Fate
message: Quotation of the Day: 'It’s like we are in a shed of cows, waiting their turn for slaughtering. After what happened with my sons, I hate all the people; I even hate myself.' - Mussalam Shalouf, who had one son executed by Hamas and another jailed on suspicion that they were collaborating with Israel.
description: Recent vigilante-style killings of seven Palestinians suspected of providing intelligence to Israel highlighted the pathetic plight of collaborators.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The Big Budget Mumble
message: 'When you put Republicans on the spot and demand specifics about how they¹re going to make good on their posturing about spending and deficits, they come up empty,' writes Op-Ed Columnist Paul Krugman.
description: Obama versus the party of no ideas.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Lines Blur as Texas Gives Industries a Bonanza
message: Under Gov. Rick Perry, Texas gives out more business incentives than any other state, around $19 billion a year, an examination by The New York Times has found. Yet the raw numbers mask a more complicated reality behind the flood of incentives and raise questions about who benefits more, the businesses or the people of Texas: http://nyti.ms/VqJJnV.This examination by the New York Times is the second installment in our series exploring how business incentives impact jobs and local economies. In case you missed it, you can read the first installment here: http://nyti.ms/UbpqUI.
description: Texas offers more incentives to attract business than any other state, but questions remain about who benefits more, the companies or the people of Texas.
caption: nytimes.com

name: News Corp. Announces Its Corporate Split, and the Closing of The Daily
message: News Corporation announced additional details about its coming split into publishing and entertainment groups, as well as the news that its standalone tablet newspaper, The Daily, would cease publication.
description: Among the details of the division of News Corporation into publishing and entertainment groups was the news that its standalone tablet newspaper would cease publication.
caption: mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com

name: Questions for Pete Wells, Restaurant Critic
message: Have a question for The New York Times’ chief restaurant critic Pete Wells? Mr. Wells—whose recent review of Guy’s American Kitchen & Bar (http://nyti.ms/R1HtlG) sparked conversation across the Web —will answer selected readers’ questions Monday and Tuesday.
description: Pete Wells, the chief restaurant critic of The New York Times, will answer selected readers’ questions Monday and Tuesday.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Vietnam Veterans, Discharged Under Cloud, File Suit Saying Trauma Was Cause
message: A class-action law suit against the armed forces argues that many Vietnam veterans had post-traumatic stress disorder when they were issued other-than-honorable discharges. The suit raises two thorny issues that could affect thousands of veterans: Can they be given a diagnosis of PTSD retroactively, to their time in service, though the disorder was not identified until 1980? And if they can, should recently instituted policies intended to protect troops with PTSD be applied retroactively to their cases?
description: A suit against the armed forces argues that many Vietnam veterans had post-traumatic stress disorder when they were issued other-than-honorable discharges, and demands that their discharges be upgraded.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Taking a Stand for Office Ergonomics
message: Do you work at a standing desk? Or have you considered adjusting your workstation with a treadmill underneath for walking? As more research finds health hazards in sitting for prolonged periods, manufacturers are offering desks that let workers stand, or even walk, while toiling at the keyboard.
description: As more research finds health hazards in sitting for prolonged periods, more manufacturers are offering desks that let workers stand, or even walk, while toiling at the keyboard.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Behind a Call That Kept Nursing Home Patients in Storm’s Path
message: The recommendation that thousands of elderly, disabled and mentally ill residents remain in more than 40 nursing homes and adult homes in flood-prone areas of New York City during Hurricane Sandy had calamitous consequences. An investigation by The New York Times found that the impact was worsened by missteps that officials made in not ensuring that these facilities could protect residents.
description: The recommendation that thousands of elderly, disabled and mentally ill residents remain in more than 40 New York nursing homes and adult homes in flood-prone areas had calamitous consequences.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Young Immigrant Activists Cast a Wider Net
message: The leaders of the United We Dream network, the largest organization of youths living in the country without legal papers, voted to expand beyond their past demands for citizenship for young people, and to mobilize in support of a bill to legalize 11 million illegal immigrants in the United States.
description: Leaders of a national movement of young immigrants voted to  mobilize in support of a bill to legalize 11 million illegal immigrants in the United States.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The New York Times
message: The growing evidence of a link between head trauma and long-term, degenerative brain disease was amplified in an extensive study of athletes (including Dave Duerson and Derek Boogaard), military veterans and others who absorbed repeated hits to the head. Learn more: http://nyti.ms/RxilDz.
description: See what an athlete's brain looks like after a history of routine hits to the head in sports like football and hockey: http://nyti.ms/UkVYxT. The photos illustrate the deterioration of the brain that can be caused by chronic traumatic encephalopathy (C.T.E.).
caption: NULL

name: New Love: A Short Shelf Life
message: Science tells us that 'wedded bliss has but a limited shelf life,' writes Opinion contributor Sonja Lyubomirsky. 'When married couples reach the two-year mark, many mistake the natural shift from passionate love to companionate love for incompatibility and unhappiness.' How should a wife or husband respond? Ms. Lyubomirsky offers a few suggestions.
description: The thrill fades almost as quickly as the joy of a new job, new home or new coat.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Mars Rover Discovery Revealed
message: In a sand drift on Mars, NASA’s Curiosity rover discovered ... sand. After all the speculation about the discovery by the Curiosity rover, scientists played down the finding, saying it did not provide definitive evidence for the building blocks of life as some had speculated.
description: After all the speculation about the discovery by the Curiosity rover, scientists played down the finding, saying that it was too early to say what they found in a pinch of sand.
caption: thelede.blogs.nytimes.com

name: Spate of Harsh Weather in New England Shifts Sentiment on Trees
message: Quotation of the Day: 'You’d think we lived in Kansas. Things like this don’t happen in western Massachusetts.' - Heather Mercier, a retired police officer, after trees crashed into her house and into the mobile home where she and her husband were living while the house was repaired.
description: After a period of violent weather, the region’s sugar maples, birches and oaks are as much a source of terror as they are of pride.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Bloomberg Asked Clinton to Consider Succeeding Him as Mayor
message: Mayor Clinton? Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg encouraged Hillary Rodham Clinton to consider entering the 2013 New York City mayor’s race, trading international diplomacy for municipal management on the grandest scale. She would, he suggested, be a perfect fit.What would you like Hillary Rodham Clinton to do after she retires as the U.S. secretary of state?
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s overture to Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton was rejected, but it may signal his dissatisfaction with the current candidates.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Republicans Balk at Obama’s Short-Term Stimulus
message: Republicans and Democrats are struggling to find common ground on a long-term debt deal. But as economic growth has weakened this quarter, they are at odds over what the flagging recovery needs in the immediate future, too. Follow our 'Debt Reckoning' blog for the latest updates on the debt talks: http://nyti.ms/VtxQxy
description: The president claims the economy needs a shot in the arm now, but Republicans say the nation should not widen the deficit.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Assad Facing Setbacks as Syrian Capital Is Besieged
message: Fierce fighting on the battlefield and setbacks on the diplomatic front increased pressure on the embattled Syrian government as fresh signs have emerged of a sustained battle for control of the capital, Damascus.
description: After a Turkish official said that Russia had backed a move seeking regime change, fresh signs emerged of a sustained battle for control of the capital.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Timeline Photos
message: How would you say 'light year' in sign language? Scientific terms like “microbiology” and “photosynthesis” have no widely accepted equivalent in sign language, so deaf students and professionals have unexpected hurdles when talking about science. Go to http://nyti.ms/VxltNl and watch Lydia Callis, a professional sign language interpreter, translate a shortened version of our article explaining how new signs are being developed that may enhance scientific learning and communication.
description: NULL
caption: NULL

name: Pro Football’s Violent Toll
message: “There’s something rotten in the N.F.L.,” Op-Ed columnist Frank Bruni writes, examining how the murder-suicide involving Kansas City Chiefs linebacker Jovan Belcher raises questions about the destructive culture of pro football. It is “an obviously dysfunctional culture that either brings out sad, destructive behavior in its fearsome gladiators or fails to protect them and those around them from it.”
description: The bloody end of the Kansas City Chiefs linebacker Jovan Belcher raises broader questions about the destructive culture of pro football.
caption: nytimes.com

name: More Dads Buy the Toys, So Barbie, and Stores, Get Makeovers
message: Barbie construction sets and pastel-colored legos are just two examples underscoring a huge shift in the toy marketplace. Fathers are doing more of the family shopping just as girls are being encouraged more than ever by hyper vigilant parents to play with toys (as boys already do) that develop math and science skills early on. Do you think such toy sets aimed at girls could be beneficial?
description: Toy makers are seizing on a marketplace shift that has more fathers making buying decisions as girls are increasingly encouraged to play with toys that develop math and science skills.
caption: nytimes.com

name: After Hurricane Sandy, Dunes Prove They Blunt Storms
message: Dune barriers acted like soft sea walls made of sand and vegetation that even when flattened or breached still managed to protect places like Westhampton Beach on Long Island, Plumb Beach in Brooklyn, and Bradley Beach in Monmouth County, N.J., by blunting the attack of surging waves and tides from Hurricane Sandy. Do you think more coastal communities should consider sea wall or dune building projects?
description: Dunes protected several communities from catastrophic damage during Hurricane Sandy, while Long Beach, N.Y., which built no dunes, suffered $200 million in losses.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Michigan Town Woos Hollywood, but Ends Up With a Bit Part
message: The idea was to build a studio on the ruins of an automobile plant that would attract prestigious filmmakers to a Michigan town and pump money into the local economy. But in Pontiac, happy endings do not usually come Hollywood-style.
description: The idea was to build a studio on the ruins of an automobile plant that would attract prestigious filmmakers to a Michigan town and pump money into the local economy. But in Pontiac, happy endings do not usually come Hollywood-style.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Where Have You Gone, Bill Buckley?
message: “Republicans must now identify those who can bring adult supervision back to the party,” writes Op-Ed contributor David Welch, who argues that the party is crying out for someone in the mold of William F. Buckley Jr. “We need officials like former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey,” who Mr. Welch says 'best represent realistic, levelheaded conservatism.”
description: The Republican Party is crying out for someone in the mold of William F. Buckley Jr.
caption: nytimes.com

name: O’Keeffe’s Hawaii
message: Early in 1939, Georgia O’Keeffe, the artist most famous for depicting the arid Southwest, suddenly decided to paint America’s diametrically opposite landscape — the lush tropical valleys of Hawaii. Today, visitors can still see Maui as she painted it.
description: Seventy-four years ago Georgia O’Keeffe discovered a tropical dreamland. Today, visitors can still see Maui as she painted it.
caption: travel.nytimes.com

name: For Young Latino Readers, an Image Is Missing
message: Quotation of the Day: 'Our students look the way they look every single day of the year, not just on Cinco de Mayo or Puerto Rican Day.' - Kimberly Blake, a teacher at a Philadelphia elementary school with a predominantly Hispanic student body, who said she struggles to find books about Latino children.
description: Educators say grade-school students develop reading skills better when they are engaged by books full of characters with whom they can identify. For Hispanic children, that’s hard to find.
caption: nytimes.com

name: After Fatal Subway Shove, Asking: Were There No Heroes?
message: The question of the day in New York City on Tuesday was 'what would you do?'  What would you do if you were pushed to the subway tracks? Or if you were standing beside someone who was pushed?
description: Images of a man’s last moments on a subway track provoked outrage and discussion about what bystanders should — or could — have done.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The Affordable Housing Crisis
message: “With nearly nine million households teetering on the verge of homelessness, the country clearly needs more support for affordable housing, not less,” states an editorial in today's Opinion Pages. The editorial includes a few suggestions on how President Obama and Congress can create more affordable housing programs.
description: Too little has been done to help poor renters. Now there is a fresh chance to change course.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Typhoon Kills Hundreds in Philippines
message: Rescue teams were trying to reach isolated villages in the southern Philippines on Wednesday after a powerful out-of-season typhoon tore through the region, leaving more than 270 people dead, officials said.
description: Rescuers sought to reach isolated villages Wednesday after a typhoon struck the region, killing at least 270 people.
caption: nytimes.com

name: IAmA Washington bureau chief of The New York Times. Ask Me Anything. : IAmA
message: David Leonhardt, the Washington bureau chief of The New York Times, is participating in an 'Ask Me Anything' discussion on the web site Reddit today. Join him at 2 PM ET for a discussion of the debt negotiations, the 2012 election, the next four years and more.
description: I'm David Leonhardt, the Washington bureau chief of The New York Times, overseeing the work of our paper's reporters who cover politics and policy in ...
caption: reddit.com

name: Dave Brubeck, Who Helped Put Jazz Back in Vogue, Dies at 91
message: “One of the reasons I believe in jazz,” Dave Brubeck once said, “is that the oneness of man can come through the rhythm of your heart. It’s the same anyplace in the world, that heartbeat. It’s the first thing you hear when you’re born — or before you’re born — and it’s the last thing you hear.” Look back at the life and work of Dave Brubeck.
description: The 1959 recording of “Take Five” was the first jazz single to sell a million copies. With other hits like “Blue Rondo à la Turk” and “Time Out,” Mr. Brubeck landed on the pop charts.
caption: nytimes.com

name: In Tax Fight, G.O.P. Seeks a Position to Fall Back On
message: With President Obama winning public support for higher tax rates on the rich, Congressional Republicans find themselves in a difficult political spot and are quietly beginning the search for a way out.
description: With President Obama winning public support for higher tax rates on the rich, Congressional Republicans find themselves in a difficult political spot and are quietly beginning the search for a way out.
caption: nytimes.com

name: How Crash Cover-Up Altered China’s Succession
message: A post on a Chinese social networking site that appeared to come from Ling Gu, the son of a high-powered aide to China’s president, helped quash reports that he had been killed in a Ferrari crash after a night of partying. It emerged later that the message was a sham, posted by someone under Mr. Ling’s alias, and the ploy has had momentous consequences for the Chinese Communist Party’s leadership succession last month.
description: The effort to suppress news of a deadly Ferrari crash, insiders  now reveal, hastened departing president Hu Jintao’s decline and spurred the ascent of China’s new leader Xi Jinping.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Pro Football Makes a Play for India
message: “We didn’t even know it was called American football,” said Linesh Mane, a defensive back in the new Elite Football League of India. “We thought it was rugby.” While the league, aimed at introducing the American sport to South Asia, is a perhaps a curious undertaking, it could prove to be lucrative.
description: The Elite Football League of India, a curious venture aimed at introducing the American sport to South Asia, has a low level of play but a large potential audience.
caption: nytimes.com

name: To Fight Climate Change, College Students Take Aim at the Endowment Portfolio
message: Students at dozens of college campuses are demanding that university endowment funds rid themselves of coal, oil and gas stocks. The students see it as a tactic that could force climate change, barely discussed in the presidential campaign, back onto the national political agenda.
description: Students are demanding that university endowment funds rid themselves of coal, oil and gas stocks in hopes of bringing climate change onto the national political agenda.
caption: nytimes.com

name: When My Friend Ellen Grossman Met Jay-Z
message: 'I think the world is in the mood for a sweet old lady,' said Ellen Grossman. Read how this largely anonymous New York artist became the 'Amiable New Yorker Who Asked Jay-Z if He Was Famous as He Was on the Way to Performing at the Barclays Center.'
description: The video showing a subway encounter between a passenger and the rapper Jay-Z has brought my friend Ellen, an artist, much new attention. Of course, she also was called 'an adorable old lady.'
caption: mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com

name: In Fine Print of Fiscal Debate, Charities Unite to Defend Deductions
message: Quotation of the Day: 'We’re like Rip Van Winkle waking up and saying, This is not O.K.!' - Diana Aviv, chief executive of Independent Sector, an umbrella group for nonprofits, on tax proposals that they fear could reduce charitable contributions.
description: Growing support for eliminating some of the tax breaks that high-income households get for charitable giving has some nonprofit groups worried.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Tanks Deployed in Cairo After Night of Deadly Clashes
message: An elite Egyptian unit deployed tanks outside the presidential palace on Thursday after a night of battles between Islamists and secular protesters that left five people dead and 450 wounded, spreading chaos in one of Cairo’s wealthiest suburbs and leaving streets littered with debris and burned-out cars.
description: An elite Egyptian unit positioned tanks outside the presidential palace in Cairo early Thursday after battles between Islamists and secular protesters that left at least five people dead.
caption: nytimes.com

name: U.S.-Approved Weapons Transfer Ended Up With Libyan Jihadis
message: The Obama administration secretly gave its blessing to arms shipments to Libyan rebels from Qatar last year, but American officials later grew alarmed as evidence grew that Qatar was turning some of the weapons over to Islamic militants.
description: The Obama administration secretly gave its blessing to arms shipments to Libyan rebels from Qatar, but American officials grew alarmed at evidence that Qatar was turning some of the weapons over to militants.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Jim DeMint to Leave Senate to Run Heritage Foundation
message: Senator Jim DeMint has long been a leading figure in the Tea Party movement. He will leave the Senate in January to lead the conservative Heritage Foundation in Washington, D.C.
description: Senator Jim DeMint, the conservative Republican from South Carolina, helped spark the Tea Party movement. His departure will require the state’s governor to name a successor.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Gifts That Change Lives
message: “Looking for an unusual holiday gift? How about a $60 trio of rabbits to a family in Haiti in the name of someone special?” writes Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof. Read Mr. Kristof’s annual holiday-giving guide that highlights little-known organizations doing meaningful work. “Another possible gift: tell a university student to apply for my annual win-a-trip contest!' Mr. Kristof also shared his 2013 contest announcement. Learn more about the contest here: http://nyti.ms/Vmfjh7Want to receive Nicholas D. Kristof's Facebook updates directly in your newsfeed? Follow him here: http://www.facebook.com/kristof
description: If you are looking for ways to say Happy Holidays that are noble and truly make a difference, here are some little-known organizations doing meaningful work.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Oscar Niemeyer, Modernist Architect of Brasília, Dies at 104
message: Oscar Niemeyer, the celebrated Brazilian architect whose flowing designs infused Modernism with a new sensuality and captured the imaginations of generations of architects around the world, died on Wednesday in Rio de Janeiro. Look back at the life and work of Mr. Niemeyer.
description: Mr. Niemeyer, the Brazilian architect, created flowing designs infused Modernism with a new sensuality and captured the imaginations of generations of architects worldwide.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Timeline Photos
message: It’s on. Two of our journalists are battling it out over the best holiday food gift. Which would you rather receive: A savory assortment of chocolate straws, melted peppers and marinated cheese rounds (http://nyti.ms/TV4DWr) or a Southern-inspired spread of cheese straws, sweet spiced pecans and hot fudge (http://nyti.ms/SJcrxm)?
description: NULL
caption: NULL

name: A Dark and Itchy Night
message: Bedbugs have discovered a new way to hitchhike in and out of beds: library books. And best-sellers that have rested on many night tables are high-risk. “You probably don’t want to check out a popular book,” said Philip Koehler, a professor of entomology. “Maybe try old history books.”
description: Bedbugs reveal a taste in literature, turning up in library books.
caption: nytimes.com

name: State May Oversee Detroit’s Finances
message: Detroit, once the nation’s fourth-largest city but one where the population has slipped, has long grappled financial woes. Now straining to manage its debts and meet its payroll, the city may be nearing circumstances dire enough to require the state to step in.
description: The city, straining to manage its debts and meet its payroll, may be nearing circumstances dire enough to require the state to step in, Michigan officials warned.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Test Your Rolling Stones Style Knowledge
message: The Rolling Stones are celebrating their 50th year together. Think you know your Stones style history? Test yourself with this quiz. What was your score?
description: Think you know your Stones style history? Test yourself, and no Googling the answers!
caption: nytimes.com

name: The New York Times
message: Here's a helpful update on the debt talks: http://nyti.ms/UhldPc. Break down President Obama and the House Republicans' offers in the debt negotiations.
description: Explore our interactive graphic breaking down what the Obama administration and the House Republicans have offered in the negotiations over the nation’s fiscal path: http://nyti.ms/UhldPc
caption: NULL

name: Parasites Use Sophisticated Biochemistry to Take Over Their Hosts
message: Zombie caterpillars attack!
description: Parasitic zombies in nature are far from rare. But only recently have scientists started to work out the sophisticated biochemistry that the parasites use.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The New York Times
message: O Christmas tree, thy leaves are so, well, unchanging. Researchers are trying to develop a Christmas tree that will hold onto its needles from Thanksgiving to New Year’s — not a small thing in a $1 billion industry. http://nyti.ms/VmNqFF
description: A seven-foot evergreen will bear 350,000 needles, more or less. And if Gary Chastagner, who heads up a Christmas tree research lab, has his way this holiday season, precious few of them will end up on the parlor floor. http://nyti.ms/VmNqFF (Photo by Randy Harris/The New York Times)
caption: NULL

name: A Chat with Michael Caine: Award Season 2013
message: Set aside a few minutes to watch this acting lesson from Michael Caine.When you're done, read about how he ended up playing Alfred the butler to Christian Bale's Batman, and more: http://nyti.ms/Xw4Zcl
description: Cinema fixture Michael Caine gives Melena Ryzik an interview (and an acting lesson) at the Four Seasons restaurant. Read full article: http://nyti.ms/XuLr8a
caption: youtube.com

name: Horrific Fire Revealed a Gap in Safety for Global Brands
message: Quotation of the Day: 'They killed time. Time was so precious, so important. But they said it was a false alarm.' - Abu Nayeem Mohammad Shahidullah, director general of Bangladesh’s national fire service, on the actions of some managers during a fatal fire at a garment factory.
description: A blaze that killed 112 workers in Bangladesh last month has exposed a glaring disconnect among global clothing brands, the monitoring system used to protect workers and the factories actually filling the orders.
caption: nytimes.com

name: U.S. Adds 146,000 Jobs; Jobless Rate Falls to 7.7%
message: The United States economy added 146,000 jobs and the unemployment rate fell to 7.7 percent in November. The jobless rate was the lowest since December 2008. The strength of the numbers was all the more notable because many experts expected a muted jobs performance because of the impact of Hurricane Sandy, which hit the East Coast on Oct. 31.
description: Economists had estimated the Labor Department would report that only 86,000 jobs were created in November.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Apple to Resume U.S. Manufacturing
message: Apple plans to join a small but growing number of companies that are bringing some manufacturing jobs back to the United States. Some analysts are hopeful that the move by such a big, innovative company could inspire a broader renaissance in American manufacturing, but a number of experts remain skeptical.
description: Some analysts are hopeful that the move by a big, innovative company like Apple could inspire a broader renaissance in American manufacturing, but a number of experts remain skeptical.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Thanks for Not Sharing
message: “There is a new urge to behave as if life were some global high-school reunion at which everyone has taken some horrific tell-all drug,” writes Op-Ed columnist Roger Cohen on what he calls the “unctuous ooze of status updates” on Facebook and Twitter. “I overshare therefore I am.”
description: There is a new urge to behave as if life were some global high-school reunion at which everyone has taken a horrific tell-all drug.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Hamas Leader Makes First Visit to Gaza
message: Khaled Meshal, whom the Israelis tried to assassinate in Jordan in 1997, arrived for his first visit to the Gaza Strip on Friday as head of the political bureau of Hamas.
description: Khaled Meshal, whom the Israelis tried to assassinate in Jordan in 1997, arrived for his first visit to the Gaza Strip on Friday as head of the political bureau of Hamas.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Two Laws Are Welcomed After Midnight in Seattle
message: Last month, Washington State voters passed ballot measures approving same sex-marriage and legalizing possession of up to an ounce of marijuana for those 21 and older. At 12:01 Thursday morning, gay couples and recreational marijuana users ushered in their new status.
description: Gay couples and recreational marijuana users in Washington State stayed up late to usher in their new status.
caption: nytimes.com

name: ‘Hyde Park on Hudson,’ With Bill Murray and Laura Linney
message: Bill Murray, who portrays Franklin D. Roosevelt, and Laura Linney star in “Hyde Park on Hudson,” which opens on Friday in some parts of the country. Do you want to see this movie? Here is Manohla Dargis’s review. Read this interview with Mr. Murray as he takes The Times's Dave Itzkoff on an adventure: http://nyti.ms/ReHD9H
description: Bill Murray portrays Franklin D. Roosevelt in “Hyde Park on Hudson,” which depicts a dalliance with his cousin Daisy Suckley.
caption: movies.nytimes.com

name: Cairo Protesters Take to Streets as Political Crisis Deepens
message: With the country’s main political blocs locked in fierce confrontation, Egypt’s turmoil seemed likely to deepen on Friday as an opposition coalition rejected a dialogue proposed by President Mohamed Morsi and thousands of rival demonstrators poured into the streets.
description: After President Mohamed Morsi vowed to proceed on a contested Islamist-backed constitution, an opposition coalition on Friday rejected his call for talks, as protests continued.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The New York Times
message: President Obama’s insistence that marginal tax rates rise for families making more than $250,000 has convinced millions of affluent Americans that they are likely to be writing larger checks to the government next year. But many of those families have no reason to fret. http://nyti.ms/VQ1Ksa
description: President Obama says he wants married couples to pay higher taxes on income above $250,000. But his plan actually excludes most joint filers making less than $300,000 — and many who make more. http://nyti.ms/RHKzeK
caption: NULL

name: National Network for First Responders Is Years Away
message: Planning delays, lack of money and limitations in technology have combined to slow creation of the post-Sept. 11 planned nationwide communications system for the police, firefighters and other first responders. “To think that you can build a network that can withstand anything and everything that Mother Nature throws at it is a bit unrealistic,” said Bill Smith, president of AT&T Network Operations. “It’s not impossible, but it would be incredibly expensive.”
description: Planning delays, lack of money and limitations in technology have slowed the creation of a communications network for the police, firefighters and others.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Supreme Court Agrees to Hear Two Cases on Gay Marriage
message: The Supreme Court announced today that it will hear arguments next year about two laws, one state and one federal, that define marriage as being between one man and one woman. How do you think the justices will rule on gay marriage?
description: The justices agreed to hear cases from New York and California contesting state and federal laws that that limit the definition of marriage to the union of a man and a woman.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Best Bets for Finding the Snow
message: Forget racing down the slopes. The sport skiers have had to master in recent years has been chasing the snow. Last season, American resorts reported the lowest average snowfall in 20 years. So how can skiers avoid ruined runs? Here are three strategies.
description: Last season, American resorts reported the lowest average snowfall in 20 years. So how can skiers avoid ruined runs? Here are three strategies.
caption: travel.nytimes.com

name: The New York Times
message: In 2012, the traditional Hollywood hierarchy was overturned. Women ruled. Discover Hollywood's heroines: http://nyti.ms/TPI7iu.
description: See the 13 actresses who gave the dreamiest performances of the year: http://nyti.ms/SMc9pA. Watch our exclusive mini-movies (http://nyti.ms/TMkOYU) of the actresses as superheroes, snake charmers and rainmakers.Photo: Quvenzhané Wallis of “Beasts of the Southern Wild.” (Credit: Tierney Gearon for The New York Times)
caption: NULL

name: Forgotten in Iraq: Struggling to Help Iraqi Allies in Danger - Op-Docs
message: Watch this Op-Doc video about the difficulties with granting asylum in the United States to many Iraqis who aided Americans after the overthrow of Saddam Hussein.Is President Obama to blame for the dangers many now face?
description: Kirk Johnson, a former U.S.A.I.D. employee, struggles to help resettle Iraqis whose lives are in danger because of their loyalty to the United States. Is Pre...
caption: youtube.com

name: Rebel Groups in Syria Make Framework for Military
message: Quotation of the Day: 'If we see any rockets and missiles, it will probably be the ones fired at us.' - Ahmad al-Qanatri, the commander of a rebel military battalion in Syria, on promised weapons.
description: After three days of intensive talks, military commanders of the main Free Syrian Army units from all over Syria agreed Friday to a unified command structure.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The True Meaning of Hanukkah
message: Op-Ed contributor Hilary Leila Krieger writes, 'The original miracle of Hanukkah was that a committed band of people led a successful uprising against a much larger force, paving the way for Jewish independence and perhaps keeping Judaism itself from disappearing.'
description: Hanukkah’s elevation as a widely celebrated holiday ignores and sanitizes its historical basis and real meaning.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The iPad as a Hand-Held Darkroom
message: Are you passionate about photography? Here are a few recommended photo editing apps and other helpful tips on how to use an iPad as a hand-held darkroom.
description: Using the Apple tablet rather than a computer for photo editing makes adjusting and sharing pictures easier.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Texas A&M Freshman Quarterback Johnny Manziel Wins Heisman Trophy
message: Johnny Football has won the Heisman Trophy.That's Johnny Manziel, the starting quarterback for Texas A&M University. He is the first freshman to win the most prestigious award in college football.
description: Quarterback Johnny Manziel threw for more than 3,000 yards and rushed for more than 1,000, raising his profile when he led Texas A&M past then-No. 1 Alabama.
caption: nytimes.com

name: A Family, for a Few Days a Year
message: Quotation of the Day: 'There’s this hope in you that doesn’t want to die. In my heart, he’s my son.' - Amy Carr, of Reno, Nev., on a 6-year-old who has lived in a Guatemalan orphanage for years because of a crackdown on adoption.
description: Hundreds of children have been stranded in orphanages in Guatemala for years as authorities there weigh whether to approve their adoptions to families in the United States.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Hillary Clinton’s Countless Choices Hinge on One: 2016
message: What would you like to see Hillary Rodham Clinton do next? With her tenure as Secretary of State coming to an end, Hillary Rodham Clinton appears to be a figure of nearly limitless possibility, but her next few years could ultimately be defined by her plans for the 2016 election. How should she navigate the nonstop speculation about 2016?
description: With her tenure as Secretary of State coming to an end, Hillary Rodham Clinton appears to be a figure of nearly limitless possibility, but her next few years could ultimately be defined by her plans for the 2016 election.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Wide-Awake: Hollywood Heroines From 2012
message: Watch: 13 actresses, who gave the dreamiest performances of 2012, employ super powers in these exclusive mini-movies for The New York Times Magazine. This year's super 13 are: Jennifer Lawrence, Keira Knightley, Rebel Wilson, Anne Hathaway, Kerry Washington, Elle Fanning, Helen Hunt, Amy Adams, Emmanuelle Riva, Naomi Watts, Shirley MacLaine, Quvenzhané Wallis and Marion Cotillard. Discover Hollywood's year of heroine worship: http://nyti.ms/SJZoKW
description: Ingénues, icons, action heroes, divas and the world's next great comedy star: 13 actresses who gave the dreamiest performances of 2012. Related video interac...
caption: youtube.com

name: Same-Sex Issue Pushes Justices Into Overdrive
message: Quotation of the Day: 'We are at a major turning point in the arc of gay and lesbian rights. The cases are moving fast, and the country is as well.' - Suzanne B. Goldberg, a law professor at Columbia, on the recent decision by the Supreme Court to hear cases on same-sex marriage.
description: The Supreme Court’s speedy decision to hear two cases on gay marriage could result in a split decision that would provide benefits to couples in some states, but permit other states to forbid same-sex marriages.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Racetrack Drugs Put Europe Off U.S. Horse Meat
message: For decades, American horses, many of them retired or damaged racehorses, have been shipped to Canada and Mexico, where it is legal to slaughter horses, and then processed and sold for consumption in Europe and beyond.Lately, however, European food safety officials have notified Mexican and Canadian slaughterhouses of a growing concern: The meat of American racehorses may be too toxic to eat safely because the horses have been injected repeatedly with drugs.
description: European consumers of horse meat are increasingly suspicious of a supply chain that they fear contains drugs injected in American racehorses.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Robots and Robber Barons
message: “The American economy is still, by most measures, deeply depressed. But corporate profits are at a record high,” Paul Krugman writes in his Opinion column. Read more about how profits have been rising at the expense of workers, “including workers with skills that were supposed to lead to success in today’s economy.”
description: Why are workers being left behind?
caption: nytimes.com

name: China to Be No. 1 Economy Before 2030, Study Says
message: An intelligence assessment of global trends projects that China will outstrip the United States as the leading economic power before 2030, but that America will remain an indispensable world leader, bolstered by energy independence.
description: The intelligence assessment also says the United States will remain an indispensable world leader, bolstered by energy independence.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Ask Alex Gansa and Howard Gordon About 'Homeland'
message: Do you watch “Homeland”? Have any questions about its array of twisted plots, dead bodies and tortured love triangles? As anticipation builds for Sunday’s season finale, the co-creators of the show are answering questions from New York Times readers this week.
description: The co-creators of 'Homeland' will answer questions from readers this week.
caption: artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com

name: U.N. Ambassador Questioned on U.S. Role in Congo Violence
message: How do you think the United States should respond to the crisis in Congo? Critics of the Obama administration’s Africa policy are focusing on the role of Susan E. Rice, the United States ambassador to the United Nations and a leading contender to succeed Hillary Clinton as Secretary of State, in the administration’s failure to take action against the country they see as a major cause of the Congolese crisis, Rwanda.
description: Critics say that the United States ambassador to the United Nations, Susan E. Rice, has failed to pressure Rwanda’s president to end his support for the rebel movement in Congo.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Suffer. Spend. Repeat.
message: Tired of hearing 'White Christmas' on permanent rotation while shopping? “Evidence suggests that the less comfortable you are during the seasonal shopping spree, the more money you’ll spend,” Oliver Burkeman writes in Opinion. “So stores crank up music, repeat the same songs, over and over again, pipe in smells, race shoppers around to far-flung points of purchase and clog their heads with confusing offers.”
description: Holiday shopping is designed to make you uncomfortable.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Jenni Rivera, 43, Mexican-American Singer and TV Star, Dies
message: Look back at the life and work of Jenni Rivera. The Mexican-American singer and reality television star, known as “the Diva of Banda,” died early Sunday when the plane in which she was traveling crashed outside Monterrey, Mexico, after a performance there.
description: Ms. Rivera was one of the biggest stars of banda, a brassy, percussive form of Spanish-language pop music.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Many Mobile Apps for Children Fall Short on Disclosure to Parents, F.T.C. Report Says
message: Only 20 percent of children’s apps provided disclosures about their data collection practices, according to a report from the Federal Trade Commission. The report also found that most apps failed to tell parents when they involved interactive features like advertising, social network sharing or allowing children to make purchases for virtual goods within the app.
description: Only 20 percent of children’s apps provided disclosures about their data collection practices, according to a staff report from the Federal Trade Commission released on Monday.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Lower Manhattan Residents and Businesses Still Grapple With Recovery
message: Since Hurricane Sandy, leaders estimate 3,000 apartments in lower Manhattan remain uninhabitable and 10,000 jobs have been lost. “The nightmare I’m fighting day and night is this vision of the downtown area filled with empty shops and ‘for rent’ signs,” said Ro Sheffe, who will lead a disaster-relief task force for small businesses. “That’s something that we saw after September 11 and I never want to see it again.”
description: Since Hurricane Sandy, local leaders estimate 3,000 apartments in the area remain uninhabitable and 10,000 jobs have been lost.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Concussion Liability Costs May Rise, and Not Just for N.F.L.
message: Are the N.F.L.’s insurers liable in the raft of lawsuits brought by former players who accuse the league of hiding information about the dangers of concussions? If so, how much money are the insurance companies obligated to pay? This dispute between the N.F.L. and its insurers could also hurt teams, leagues and schools at all levels in hockey, lacrosse and other contact sports.
description: The N.F.L.’s legal battles also involve how much money, if any, insurers are obligated to pay, and the dispute could hurt teams, leagues and schools at all levels in other contact sports.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The Lives They Loved: Share Your Photos
message: Do you have a loved one who passed away this year? Share a photo and story about that person's life on the page linked here: http://nyti.ms/UuqJ0Z. Your photo may be featured online or in the printed 'The Lives They Lived' issue of The New York Times Magazine. Today, Dec. 10, is the deadline for submissions. You can browse readers' submissions from 2011 here: http://nyti.ms/TMOHGa
description: For our coming The Lives They Lived issue, an annual celebration of some of the most intriguing people who have died over the past year, we are inviting you to contribute a photograph that illustrates a story from the life of someone close to you who passed away in 2012. It could be a wedding snapsh...
caption: submit.nytimes.com

name: In Girl’s Last Hope, Altered Immune Cells Beat Leukemia
message: Emma Whitehead is the first child and one of the first humans ever in whom new techniques have achieved a long-sought goal — giving a patient’s own immune system the lasting ability to fight cancer. It is hard to believe, but last spring Emma, then 6, was near death from acute lymphoblastic leukemia. She is now in complete remission after an experimental treatment in which a disabled form of the virus that causes AIDS reprogrammed Emma’s immune system genetically to kill cancer cells.
description: Emma Whitehead, 7, has been in full remission for months after scientists used a disabled form of H.I.V. to reprogram her immune system to kill cancer cells.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Obesity in Young Is Seen as Falling in Several Cities
message: Quotation of the Day: 'It’s been nothing but bad news for 30 years, so the fact that we have any good news is a big story.' - Dr. Thomas Farley, health commissioner in New York, one of several cities reporting a decline in the number of obese schoolchildren.
description: The declines are small but significant because they offer the first indication that the obesity epidemic, one of the nation’s most intractable health problems, may be reversing course.
caption: nytimes.com

name: A Hunger for Tales of Life in the American Cul-de-Sac
message: Russians are making a surprise hit out of Nikolai V. Zlobin’s “America – What a Life!”, a book that sees teenage baby sitters, an aversion to hard liquor and leaving the curtains open at night as part of everyday life in the United States.
description: Russians are making a surprise hit out of a book that sees teenage baby sitters and an aversion to hard liquor as basics in the United States.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Pentagon Says Afghan Forces Still Need Assistance
message: As President Obama considers how quickly to withdraw the remaining 68,000 American troops in Afghanistan and turn over the war to Afghan security forces, a new Pentagon report has found that only one of the Afghan National Army’s 23 brigades is able to operate independently without military support from the United States and NATO partners.
description: Just one of 23 Afghan brigades is able to operate on its own without air or other military support from the United States or NATO, the report found.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Social Science Palooza III
message: Did you know that organic foods may make you less generous? That men are dumber around women? That birth date affects corporate success? These are just some of the recent research findings in social studies that David Brooks shares in his Op-Ed column. These studies “remind us that we are influenced by a thousand breezes permeating the unconscious layers of our mind,” Mr. Brooks writes. “They are also nice conversation starters.”
description: Social science continues to remind us of the power of social context, and the thousands of variables that shape our unconscious. Here’s a smattering of recent research.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Florida May Reduce Tuition for Select Majors
message: Should an undergraduate student pay less for an engineering or biotechnology degree than for a degree in history or English? In Florida, the governor’s task force on higher education suggested that tuition rates be frozen for majors in “strategic areas.”
description: The governor’s task force on higher education suggested that tuition rates be frozen, so that going to school for science would cost less than getting a liberal arts degree.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Michigan Legislature Approves Union Limit
message: Michigan is the home of the United Automobile Workers. But after votes today in its House and Senate, the state finds itself close to becoming the 24th in the nation to ban compulsory union fees. Gov. Rick Snyder, a Republican, is expecting to sign the bill later this week.
description: The bill vastly reduces the power of organized labor in Michigan, a traditional union state.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Fallen Dean’s Life, Contradictory to Its Grisly End
message: Cecilia Chang, a dean at St. John’s University in Queens, associated with a whirlwind of characters: Catholic priests, Chinese gangsters, American lawmakers, a Taiwanese general and a fantastically corrupt city politician, to name a few. She had been married three times. One husband, she had told several people, was involved in organized crime; another told the police before succumbing to gunshot wounds that she was behind the attack.Less than 24 hours after testifying in her corruption trial last month, Dr. Chang killed herself.
description: Cecilia Chang, a dean at St. John’s University, was a complicated figure, one whose descent from beauty-parlor optimism to suicide took less than two days.
caption: nytimes.com

name: A Rising Tide of Noise Is Now Easy to See
message: The ocean depths have become a noisy place because of human activity, and experts say the rising clamor is particularly dangerous to marine mammals. To fight the din, the federal government is completing the first phase of its sound mapping project that aims to curb the noise pollution and return the sprawling ecosystem to a quieter state.
description: The depths have become a noisy place because of human activity, and experts say the rising clamor is particularly dangerous to marine mammals.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Libyan Reluctance Hobbles Benghazi Assault Investigation
message: The investigation into the attacks that killed Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens and three other Americans three months ago has been hobbled by the reluctance of the Libyan authorities to move against Islamist extremist suspects who belong to powerful militias.
description: Three months after the attacks that killed Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens and three other Americans, the Libyan authorities are loath to move against Islamist extremist suspects.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Messi’s Brilliance Transcends His Numbers
message: On Sunday, soccer player Lionel Messi set an international record by scoring his 86th goal in a calendar year, delivering an average of one goal every four days, as often as Starbucks opens a new store in China. But Messi is best appreciated in the virtuosity of the moment, not against the backdrop of history and statistics.
description: Soccer’s beauty is that it surpasses statistics, unlike in baseball where numbers carry so much weight.
caption: nytimes.com

name: The Earliest Dinosaur, or Maybe Its Closest Kin
message: Is the Nyasasaurus parringtoni the earliest dinosaur? The creature, which was the size of a Labrador retriever but with a five-foot long tail, roamed the earth about 243 million years ago, 10 million years before other early dinosaurs.
description: Nyasasaurus parringtoni was the size of a Labrador retriever but with a five-foot-long tail. It roamed the earth about 243 million years ago.
caption: nytimes.com

name: Obama Says U.S. Will Recognize Syrian Rebels
